Nidoqueen.overview: Nidoqueen is both a premier offensive Stealth Rock setter and a devastating Sheer Force wallbreaker with few safe switch-ins. It can forgo Stealth Rock altogether to run a dedicated wallbreaker set, which can even get past some usual answers like Umbreon, Assault Vest Reuniclus, and Bronzong with the right moves. Nidoqueen's typing lends it crucial resistances like Fighting and an immunity to Electric, which lets it check prominent Pokemon such as Cobalion and Raikou. Most importantly, however, is having that Electric immunity without a Grass weakness, which lets it check Xurkitree and block its Volt Switch, a trait only shared by Steelix. However, Nidoqueen's lack of reliable recovery severely cuts into how long it can check a foe. At best, it might check a Pokemon like Xurkitree twice, but Nidoqueen can take full advantage of these opportunities to punish the opponent with an onslaught of Sheer Force + Life Orb boosted attacks. Nidoqueen's slightly below average Speed is just enough to get the jump on various threats such as Metagross and Bewear, but it barely misses out on a lot of other prevalent threats like Togekiss, Gardevoir, and Xurkitree. This often leads to worse matchups against fast-paced teams, as Nidoqueen will have fewer opportunities to set Stealth Rock or get an attack off against faster foes.
Nidoqueen.comments:
Other Options

A specially defensive set with Black Sludge is viable on balance and stall teams as a solid switch-in to Xurkitree, but it competes with Steelix and is harder to fit elsewhere, as more offensive teams heavily value Nidoqueen's wallbreaking ability. With Choice Scarf, Nidoqueen can outspeed and surprise KO revenge killers such as Flygon, Gardevoir, and Celebi, but outside of the surprise factor, it's generally outclassed by other Choice Scarf users due to its lower Speed tier. Nidoqueen can set Toxic Spikes, but the abundance of Poison-types such as opposing Nidoqueen and Roserade, Heavy-Duty Boots users, and ungrounded Pokemon, such as Crobat and Flygon, leaves few relevant targets for the move. Focus Blast with a Modest nature 2HKOes Umbreon and Porygon2 after Stealth Rock, but Nidoqueen already has more reliable methods to deal with both in Taunt and Toxic.

Checks and Counters

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Specially defensive Pokemon such as Assault Vest Reuniclus, Umbreon, and the rarer Porygon2 can comfortably switch into any of Nidoqueen's attacks; Reuniclus, in particular, does this well, as it out-heals any damage it takes with Regenerator. However, all of them need to watch out for Toxic, and Umbreon also fears Taunt. Snorlax can switch in with ease and use Nidoqueen as setup fodder.

Bulky Water-types: Certain bulky Water-types such as Milotic, Jellicent, and Vaporeon sport high enough special bulk to comfortably switch into Nidoqueen. However, the former two will lose in the long run to sets with Toxic, and all of them fear the rare Thunderbolt.

Faster Threats: Common faster threats such as Flygon, Starmie, and Gardevoir can outspeed and KO Nidoqueen but can't safely switch in. Gardevoir can even copy Sheer Force with Trace to boost its moves and make it harder for Nidoqueen's teammates to deal with it.

Bronzong: Thanks to Levitate, Bronzong hard counters any Nidoqueen set without Fire Blast.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Nidoqueen forces a lot of switches, which it can use to safely set Stealth Rock, and it can keep Stealth Rock up because it threatens most common entry hazard removers such as Crobat, Flygon, and Rotom-C. Ice Beam OHKOes Flygon and 2HKOes Crobat, both of which Nidoqueen can't touch without it. Sheer Force, alongside Life Orb, lets Nidoqueen OHKO or 2HKO most of the tier except the bulkiest of special walls. Still, Shuca Berry is a valid option to check Flygon and other Ground-types Nidoqueen lures in. 16 Defense EVs can be run with Shuca Berry so Nidoqueen isn't OHKOed by Outrage from Choice Band Flygon. Timid lets Nidoqueen speed tie opposing Nidoqueen and outspeed Modest variants. Modest does not miss out on other prevalent threats however, and the power is appreciated if your team can handle other Nidoqueen. 24 Special Defense EVs avoid the 2HKO from Xurkitree's Energy Ball.

Heracross, Togekiss, and Pangoro can all take advantage of Nidoqueen's switch-ins such as Assault Vest Reuniclus and Umbreon. Pivots such as Crobat and Noivern can provide free switches with U-turn against Steel- and Rock-types such as Registeel, Metagross, and Diancie. Crobat and Noivern also help check Fighting-types, which Nidoqueen can't reliably do on its own, as can Reuniclus and Galarian Weezing. Dark-types such as Umbreon, Incineroar, and Guzzlord can check Psychic-types such as Assault Vest Reuniclus and Celebi, while Steel-types such as Metagross and Escavalier can take on Calm Mind Reuniclus and Gardevoir. Umbreon deserves special mention, as it also keeps Nidoqueen healthy throughout the match with Wish. Electric- and Grass-types such as Xurkitree, Celebi, and Rotom-C take care of bulky Water-types, and Grass-types are also crucial for Electric-types like Xurkitree, Raikou, and Rotom-C, which can otherwise overwhelm Nidoqueen with either repeated strong attacks or super effective coverage. Water-types such as Milotic, Golisopod, and Vaporeon help with common Ground-types like Flygon. Golisopod also provides Spikes to help Nidoqueen out-damage Assault Vest Reuniclus's Regenerator healing and wear down other switch-ins like Umbreon, while, similarly to Umbreon, Vaporeon can heal it with Wish.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Ice Beam OHKOes Flygon and 2HKOes Crobat, which wall Nidoqueen's STAB combination. Toxic cripples switch-ins such as Assault Vest Reuniclus, Milotic, and Jellicent. On the other hand, Taunt prevents one of its most common counters, Umbreon, from healing up with Wish and ultimately lets Nidoqueen beat it. Fire Blast 2HKOes Bronzong, which otherwise completely stonewalls Nidoqueen, but it's less prevalent than Nidoqueen's other counters. Thunderbolt is an option to 2HKO bulky Water-types such as Milotic, Jellicent, and Vaporeon after Stealth Rock. The 24 Special Defense EVs ensure Energy Ball from Xurkitree doesn't 2HKO Nidoqueen. Timid is preferred for opposing Nidoqueen, but a Modest nature nets extra power while only making Nidoqueen slower than niche threats like Decidueye and Tsareena.

Wallbreakers such as Heracross, Pangoro, and Bewear can take advantage of Nidoqueen's usual answers, primarily Reuniclus and Umbreon. Special wallbreakers such as Starmie, Xurkitree, and Celebi especially appreciate Taunt Nidoqueen because it prevents special walls like Umbreon from healing. Pivots such as Crobat, Noivern, and Tornadus can provide free switches with U-turn against Steel- and Rock-types such as Registeel, Metagross, and Diancie. The former two also help Nidoqueen check Fighting-types, which it can't do on its own, while the latter can help break through Umbreon with Superpower. Steel-types such as Registeel, Metagross, Stakataka, and Bronzong halt any Psychic-types like Gardevoir and Celebi trying to take advantage of Nidoqueen. Water-types such as Milotic, Golisopod, and Vaporeon can soak up hits from Ground-types such as Flygon. Golisopod also provides Spikes, which lets Nidoqueen push past Assault Vest Reuniclus without needing Toxic and more quickly whittle down Umbreon if Nidoqueen is running Toxic. Meanwhile, Vaporeon is noteworthy for its Wish support, which keeps Nidoqueen healthy throughout the match. Grass-types such as Celebi, Dhelmise, and Roserade can deal with Water-types like Milotic and Vaporeon, and they help Nidoqueen check Electric-types such as Xurkitree, Raikou, and Rotom-C, which can otherwise overwhelm it with either repeated strong hits or super effective coverage.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Vileplume's reliable bulk and good defensive typing allow it to act as a switch-in to common threats in RU such as Mimikyu and Raikou, while its ability Effect Spore lets it potentially punish contact moves, especially U-turn from the likes of Flygon and Heliolisk. Unfortunately, Vileplume can get worn down quickly and is often forced to use its recovery to remain healthy, which gives openings to Pokemon it invites in like Chandelure and common Flying-types such as Noivern and Togekiss. Strength Sap is Vileplume's main recovery move and allows it to lower the Attack stat of an opposing physical attacker. Corrosive Gas is used to remove important items such as Leftovers, Heavy-Duty Boots, and Choice items from Pokemon such as Registeel, Crobat, and Toxtricity. Alternatively, Sleep Powder can be used to put common switch-ins such as Crobat and Noivern to sleep, generating free turns for itself and its teammates. An alternative EV spread of 252 HP / 144 Def / 112 SpD can be used to avoid a 4HKO from Xurkitree's Thunderbolt. Vileplume is best suited for balance teams that need a check for prominent physical attackers such as Sharpedo and Mimikyu. Due to Vileplume's weakness to Fire-types, bulky Water-types such as Suicune and Milotic can be great teammates. In return, Vileplume can handle offensive Electric-types such as Xurkitree and Raikou. Since Vileplume often invites in Flying-types like Crobat and Tornadus, checks to these Pokemon such as Xurkitree and Raikou are good partners. Registeel and Steelix also make great teammates for Vileplume, since they are able to check offensive Psychic-types such as Gardevoir. Since Vileplume often switches into pivots, taking damage from entry hazards can quickly wear it down and limit its defensive capabilities, so entry hazard removal from Starmie or Crobat is important.

Cloyster.overview: The following analysis is outdated and is currently being revamped. Information contained in the analysis may be misinformative in regards to the current SS RU metagame.

sets.name: Shell Smash Sweeper
sets.description:
Shell Smash Cloyster's ability to potentially break past its checks through flinches make it a threatening setup sweeper. It also takes advantage of teams relying on Seismitoad and Gastrodon as their bulky Water-type, as neither is a suitable Cloyster check. Rock Blast hits Water-types such as Milotic and Suicune neutrally, helping Cloyster beat them with flinches. It also hits Volcanion and can be used against other Fire-types like Incineroar and Chandelure. Hydro Pump is the preferred last move due to its greater damage against Steel-types such as Metagross, Cobalion, and Steelix. Liquidation can be used instead to OHKO Diancie and potentially 2HKO Registeel after Spikes damage while also giving Cloyster a more reliable Water-type STAB move. However, it makes Cloyster more reliant on breaking past the aforementioned Steel-types with flinches. King's Rock gives Cloyster's Icicle Spear and Rock Blast an effective 41% flinch chance. A Naive or Jolly nature should be used, as they allow +2 Cloyster to outrun Choice Scarf Mienshao. Explosion can be used to take down Water-types such as Milotic and Suicune for a teammate. Focus Sash can be used to almost guarantee setup, but this requires solid entry hazard removal, and Cloyster loses out on the ability to break past its checks with flinches. Life Orb is another item option that allows Cloyster to KO notable threats such as Cobalion, Galarian Weezing, Metagross, and Doublade at +2 without prior residual damage. Spikes allows Cloyster, which beats most Defoggers, to give value to its team in a matchup where it doesn't do much else. However, Spikes also forces Cloyster to ditch its Water-type STAB moves, which worsens its matchup against Steel-types significantly.

Cloyster's natural physical bulk is impressive even without investment and gives it some notable setup opportunities against Pokemon such as Darmanitan, Crobat lacking Taunt, and Mimikyu. Cloyster is potentially capable of breaking past its defensive answers with flinches, but this requires a fair bit of luck. Bulky Water- and Steel-types can halt Cloyster barring an ill-timed flinch, so efforts should be put into wearing these Pokemon down. Most of the tier's bulky Steel-types will get worn down by Spikes; offensive Metagross, Cobalion, and Doublade will be in KO range of +2 Hydro Pump after switching in with three layers of Spikes, while Liquidation variants will be able to reliably 2HKO Registeel after two layers. Therefore, Spikes setters like Klefki and Roserade are good teammates. Cloyster's ability to take advantage of Spikes and cause its targets to flinch makes it a great choice for hyper offense teams, as it can be a devastating wincon or a supportive wallbreaker for another sweeping teammate such as Necrozma, Mimikyu, or Polteageist. Cloyster is also capable of sweeping on standard offensive and bulky offensive teams. Teams utilizing Cloyster in this regard should attempt to wear down bulky Water- and Steel-types. Knock Off from the likes of Incineroar, Reuniclus, and Obstagoon can remove Leftovers from Pokemon like Registeel and Suicune, making it easier for Cloyster to break through them. Pivoting teammates, such as Mienshao, Incineroar, and Crobat, can get Cloyster into battle safely. Toxic from Diancie and Salazzle can help wear down Water-types to let Cloyster go wild late-game.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Alolan Marowak is a potent wallbreaker in RU that is also able to soft check many dangerous threats, such as Roserade, Xurkitree, and Toxtricity, due to its Lightning Rod ability and typing. Unfortunately, Alolan Marowak struggles to find wallbreaking opportunities, and it is also revenge killed easily due to its low Speed stat, vulnerability to Stealth Rock, weaknesses to common types, and mediocre bulk. Low Kick importantly covers Guzzlord, hits Snorlax hard, and deals more damage than Fire Punch to some bulky Steel-types, such as Registeel and Steelix. Earthquake 2HKOes Incineroar even with a Jolly nature and provides a stronger hit against Diancie, but misses out on Guzzlord. Swords Dance lets Alolan Marowak break through every wall in RU after one boost. Alternatively, Flame Charge alongside a Jolly nature can be used to prevent it from being outsped and revenge killed by Pokemon such as Flame Orb Heracross, Chandelure, and Nidoqueen after one boost. However, even after one boost, it is still slower than many common threats like Mimikyu, Flygon, and Noivern.

An entry hazard remover like Noivern, Crobat, or Togekiss is crucial to pair with Alolan Marowak, as every entry hazard, especially Stealth Rock, limits its ability to switch into the mentioned threats. Offensive pivots like Noivern, Xurkitree, and Raikou support Alolan Marowak with free switches into defensive Pokemon it defeats easily, such as Registeel, Assault Vest Reuniclus, and Bronzong. Roserade checks Water-types, Golisopod checks Ground-types like Flygon, and both provide Spikes support. In general, Alolan Marowak appreciates bulky teammates like Togekiss, Celebi, and Steelix, since it's easily revenge killed by many Pokemon due to its low base Speed and common weaknesses. Wish support from Togekiss and Sylveon helps Alolan Marowak to stay healthy. Powerful late-game cleaners like Choice Scarf Heracross and Choice Scarf Xurkitree appreciate Alolan Marowak's wallbreaking capabilities.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Galarian Weezing's immense physical bulk and good defensive typing make it a good check to common threats such as Mimikyu, Golisopod, and Heracross. Levitate additionally gives Weezing the ability to effectively deal with Ground-types such as Flygon, Rhyperior, and Steelix. However, Galarian Weezing's mediocre special bulk, lack of consistent recovery, and general passivity make it harder to support and fit on teams than its Fairy-type competition of Togekiss and Diancie. Sludge Bomb is preferred over Sludge Wave for its higher chance of poisoning. Galarian Weezing can be used as a Defogger, though it dislikes some Stealth Rock setters such as Metagross and Nidoqueen. Toxic Spikes can be useful for crippling Pokemon such as Gastrodon, Milotic, and Diancie, but it's matchup-dependent due to the prevalence of Heavy-Duty Boots and the large amount of viable Poison- and Steel-types such as Roserade, Registeel, and Metagross. It additionally faces competition from Nidoqueen for this role who offers much less passivity at the cost of some defensive utility. Pain Split gives Galarian Weezing a form of recovery, albeit an unreliable one. Will-O-Wisp burns threats such as Bewear, Mimikyu, and Cloyster. Corrosive Gas can be used to remove items from the likes of Roserade, Registeel, and Chandelure. Rest is a viable option on stall teams, but stall is a rather unreliable playstyle as a whole. Black Sludge is preferred to give Galarian Weezing more survivability. Rocky Helmet can be used to force more damage onto the likes of Golisopod and Heracross, but should only be used with dedicated Wish support. Heavy-Duty Boots can be used to mitigate entry hazard damage, but it has the same recovery issue as Rocky Helmet. Neutralizing Gas can be used over Levitate for negating abilites like Heracross's Guts, Reuniclus's Regenerator, and Cloyster's Skill Link, but it completely ruins Weezing's ability to check the aforementioned threats and can be matchup dependent in its utility.

Galarian Weezing can be used on balance and stall teams that cover for it sapping momentum and appreciate it checking threats in Heracross, Mimikyu, and Sharpedo. Pokemon such as Registeel, Snorlax, and Assault Vest Reuniclus can help against specially offensive threats to Galarian Weezing such as Salazzle, Raikou, and Celebi. Registeel and Snorlax also appreciate Galarian Weezing switching into threatening Fighting-types. Water-types such as Jellicent, Suicune, and Milotic are capable of taking on offensive Steel-types such as Cobalion and Metagross. Every Electric-type in the tier forces Galarian Weezing out, leading to free uses of Volt Switch. Gastrodon and Steelix are viable Ground-type partners as a result. Wish passing from the likes of Umbreon is useful and practically mandatory on stall, as Galarian Weezing lacks reliable recovery. Variants running Toxic Spikes can be supported by bulky Calm Mind sweepers like Suicune. Threats to Poison-types such as Nidoqueen, Gardevoir, and Flygon are important on such teams.

Starmie.overview: Starmie is a great defensive spinner that matches up well into the common entry hazard setters of the tier and can pivot. Starmie's phenomenal Speed tier and ability to force foes out with its great super effective coverage also make it an exceptional wallbreaker and allow it to take advantage of Analytic. Its bulk uninvested is unimpressive however, limiting opportunities for offensive sets to come into battle or forcing Starmie to click Recover instead of attacking. Specially defensive walls like Registeel, Assault Vest Reuniclus, and Umbreon also prove difficult to beat without Analytic boosts. Starmie has to fear being picked off by First Impression from Golisopod and other naturally fast Pokemon like Raikou and Noivern that can take advantage of Starmie's frailty and force it out.
Starmie.comments:
Other Options

Psychic provides ample neutral coverage and eases prediction but has few specific targets. Analytic boosted Choice Specs hits extremely hard, but being Choice-locked prevents it from taking advantage of its coverage.

Checks and Counters

Faster Threats and Priority: Golisopod can pick Starmie off with First Impression and Toxicroak can OHKO with boosted Sucker Punch. Starmie is also susceptible to faster Pokemon like Raikou and Noivern, which force it out.

Specially Defensive Walls: Assault Vest Reuniclus, Snorlax, and Umbreon can take any of Starmie's moves and 2HKO in return, with Umbreon being able to also heal off before so.

Bulky Water-types: Bulky Water-types such as Milotic, Jellicent, and Suicune wall defensive Starmie, but Starmie can get momentum as they switch in by using Teleport. Offensive Starmie can still be walled by bulky Water-types; however, they cannot freely switch in due to Analytic-boosted super effective coverage.

sets.name: Rapid Spin
sets.description:
Starmie is a consistent entry hazard removal option due to its favourable matchups against common hazard setters such as Rhyperior and Steelix giving it opportunity to pivot or use Rapid Spin. Teleport allows Starmie to take advantage of these entry hazard setters and get teammates in safely. Toxic is an option that cripples bulky Water-types such as Volcanion, Milotic, and Gatstrodon, although Roserade and Toxicroak can take advantage of it. Psyshock with 64 Special Attack EVs is an option to OHKO offensive Roserade.

Starmie can fit on any archetype but is preferred on entry hazard and offensive teams, assisting teammates like Heracross and Tornadus. Wallbreakers such as Toxtricity and Chandelure benefit from Teleport giving them a free switch and allowing them to threaten Starmie's checks such as Vileplume, threatening certain sets with an OHKO. Starmie's Rapid Spin and Teleport also benefit Choice Scarf Xurkitree and Calm Mind Raikou. Noivern and Crobat resist First Impression from Golisopod and stop Grass-types such as Celebi from freely setting up on Starmie; in return, Starmie's Rapid Spin allows Crobat and Noivern to run another move instead of Defog.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Starmie's expansive offensive movepool allows it to act as a powerful wallbreaker that can use super effective coverage and Analytic to break past usual Water-type checks. Hydro Pump is an option over Surf to deal more damage to neutral targets, although its accuracy is a concern due to Starmie's below-average bulk. Ice Beam hits Grass- and Dragon-types such as Celebi, Roserade, and Noivern. Grass Knot nails bulky Water-types such as Milotic, Gastrodon, and Suicune. Starmie can take advantage of forced switches to regain health with Recover and continue firing off hits. Rapid Spin is an option if a team desperately needs entry hazard removal, and it has the added benefit of potentially making Starmie a threatening cleaner with the Speed boost.

Entry hazard setters such as Roserade, Registeel, and Klefki can help Starmie pressure balance cores more easily. Pivots like Talonflame and Incineroar can bring it into Pokemon it threatens such as Diancie and Galarian Weezing. Other wallbreakers like Flygon and Calm Mind Raikou can form cores with Starmie to break down each other's checks in bulky Water- and Grass-types. Pangoro, Obstagoon, and Heracross deal with specially defensive walls like Umbreon and Porygon2. Finally, cleaners such as Sharpedo and Mimikyu take advantage of Starmie's wallbreaking to sweep.

sets.name: Revenge Killer
sets.description:
Ditto is a reliable revenge killer with good offensive matchups, since it's able to revenge kill Pokemon like Dragon Dance Flygon and Shell Smash Cloyster. It also has a good stall matchup because it can infinitely replenish PP and copy utility moves. Ditto's EVs just maximize its physical bulk and minimize Speed in case of the rare Ditto mirror matchup, while the Impish nature and 4 Speed IVs with a Choice Scarf allow it to outspeed Galarian Weezing, which can block Imposter by activating Neutralizing Gas. An alternative spread with 0 Speed IVs and a Relaxed nature maximizes Ditto's chances of winning mirror matchups.

Ditto can fit on a team mainly looking for a revenge killer to deal with a range of threats that cannot be walled by a single Pokemon and could break through the team. Thus, it's a solid pick with a defensive backbone. In return, defensive teammates can switch into offensive foes for it. Ditto can also fit on offensive teams that have very little defensive backbone, revenge killing threats that could run through the team and patching up the stall matchup. Ditto in turn appreciates offensive breakers such as Toxtricity and Heracross helping its shaky matchup against balance teams. It also needs teammates that can beat Substitute users like Suicune; countermeasures to these Pokemon include Infiltrator Pokemon such as Toxic Crobat and Noivern. Entry hazard removers like Togekiss can also be helpful for Ditto to reliably switch into threats. Cleric support from Pokemon like Umbreon and Sylveon prevents Toxic from stopping Ditto against stall teams. Finally, Knock Off absorbers like Bewear and Galarian Weezing can be vital, as Ditto losing its Choice Scarf means it will be unable to revenge kill offensive threats.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Vaporeon carves out a niche from competitors such as Milotic and Gastrodon through its ability to provide Wish and potentially cleric support to its teammates. Milotic and Gastrodon do still provide heavy competition; Milotic can more easily fit Flip Turn, while Gastrodon has a useful Ground typing and better coverage, making them significantly less passive. Furthermore, Vaporeon faces heavy competition as a cleric from Umbreon due to its typing and superior bulk, which allow Umbreon to check Chandelure better, as an example. Wish provides recovery for both Vaporeon and its teammates, while Protect ensures it can take advantage of Wish while also scouting Choice item users like Chandelure. While Heal Bell is standard, Flip Turn lets Vaporeon pivot and safely pass Wish to its teammates instead. Leftovers provides Vaporeon with passive recovery, which can be crucial throughout a long game, while Heavy-Duty Boots gives it more longevity on teams with weak or no hazard removal. Alternate EV spreads are possible for Vaporeon: 56 Speed EVs allow it to outspeed maximum Speed Rhyperior, while 96 Speed EVs outspeed Alolan Marowak.

Vaporeon fits best on bulky balance teams, as they have the staying power to take advantage of Wish and cleric support. Bulky Steel-types like Steelix and Registeel appreciate Wish and Vaporeon switching into Fire-type moves aimed at them, while they can take advantage of the Grass-types that come in on Vaporeon. Furthermore, wallbreakers such as Lucario, Alolan Marowak, and Choice Band Flygon also switch into Grass-types, as well as Electric-types. They can also take advantage of Vaporeon's Wish and Flip Turn support. Diancie can act as the team's cleric, freeing Vaporeon to use Flip Turn's slow pivoting, which is extremely potent combined with Wish. Additionally, an entry hazard remover like Crobat is a great partner, as it frees Vaporeon to run Leftovers and switches into Grass-types like Roserade.

sets.name: Rain Sweeper
sets.description:
Kabutops is a niche but potent rain attacker with access to Swords Dance that can hit most rain checks like Gastrodon neutrally. Liquidation is stronger than Waterfall, but Waterfall can give unexpected openings through flinches. Superpower lets Kabutops break past Gastrodon if it is chipped, while Aqua Jet can clean even if rain runs out. Protect can be used to prevent First Impression.

Kabutops should always be run with Politoed on dedicated rain teams. Other rain sweepers such as Kingdra, Nasty Plot Tornadus, and Ludicolo can work in tandem with Kabutops to wear down the opposing team's defensive structure. Checks to opposing Gastrodon, such as Tornadus and Ludicolo, are necessary, as Kabutops is completely walled by them. Other Pokemon that fit on rain teams like Klefki, Toxicroak, and Raikou also pair well with Kabutops.

sets.name: 3 Attacks + Roost
sets.description: Aerodactyl's natural Speed and Attack stats also make it a decent choice for an anti-offense Pokemon, outspeeding common threats like Noivern and Raikou. Earthquake guarantees OHKOs on Electric-types like Xurkitree and Heliolisk while guaranteeing 2HKOs on Steel-types like Metagross and Stakataka. Roost gives Aerodactyl reliable recovery to make up for Life Orb recoil and potential Stealth Rock chip if it's not carrying Heavy-Duty Boots. Teammates like Crobat, Dhelmise, and Starmie can provide hazard removal while also checking threats like Choice Scarf Heracross and bulkier Steel-types, respectively. Celebi, Roserade, and Xurkitree can deal with bulky Water-types like Milotic, Suicune, and Gastrodon that give Aerodactyl a hard time. Additionally, Roserade provides Spikes support to further wear down Aerodactyl's checks. Teammates like U-turn Flygon and Heliolisk that can bring in Aerodactyl safely to threaten Togekiss and Roserade, respectively, are appreciated. Choice Scarf users like Xurkitree, Rotom-C, and the aforementioned Heracross OHKO Aerodactyl. Therefore, teammates like Assault Vest Reuniclus, Nidoqueen, and Crobat are useful to check these threats.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
Dragon Dance allows Aerodactyl to function as a dangerous setup sweeper. One boost from Dragon Dance lets Aerodactyl OHKO threats like offensive Metagross while being faster than most Choice Scarf users, including Flygon and Heracross. Earthquake hits Steel-types like Steelix, Stakataka, and Metagross that resist both STAB moves. Life Orb is preferred, but Heavy-Duty Boots does grant Aerodactyl Stealth Rock immunity and lacks Life Orb's recoil, which makes setting up easier. An Adamant nature lets Aerodactyl hit harder, while a Jolly nature lets it outspeed Noivern and Raikou unboosted. Unnerve prevents threats like Metagross from using their Shuca Berry and eating up an Earthquake.

Bulky Water-types like Milotic, Suicune, and Gastrodon eat up Aerodactyl's moves and check it, so teammates like Celebi, Roserade, and Toxtricity are appreciated. Celebi serves as a Scald switch-in that can set up on Water-types. Roserade provides Spikes support to wear down said Water-types as well as a super effective Grass attack. Bulky Pokemon that resists Aerodactyl's STABs like Rhyperior, Steelix, and Registeel can be problematic, as they can take a boosted Earthquake when healthy. Teammates like Milotic, Nidoqueen, and Heracross handle them with minimal fuss. A partner like Golisopod or Choice Specs Gardevoir can wear down Steel-types to put them in OHKO range of Aerodactyl's attacks. Teammates like Dhelmise and Registeel that appreciate Aerodactyl pressuring threats like Noivern, Chandelure, and Fighting-types work as partners. Dhelmise is notable because it provides Rapid Spin support for Aerodactyl using Life Orb. Other notable entry hazard control teammates include Starmie and Tsareena to check threats like Bronzong.

Snorlax.overview: Notice: This analysis is outdated and is currently being revamped at (https://www.smogon.com/forums/threads/snorlax.3692016/)

sets.name: Curselax
sets.description:
Snorlax's overall bulk and access to Curse enable it to check Fire- and Electric-types such as Chandelure, Darmanitan, and Raikou. However, Snorlax's typing leaves it with no resistances, making it unable to switch into powerful Pokemon such as Choice Specs Toxtricity and Indeedee-M. Curse enables Snorlax to have immense sweeping potential while also letting it threaten its checks. Body Slam inflicts paralysis, making it easier for Snorlax to get boosts from Curse while helping its teammates by slowing down faster threats. Earthquake provides great coverage against Normal-resistant and -immune Pokemon like Cobalion and Alolan Marowak. Rest is Snorlax's main recovery move while also being able to remove status effects. Thick Fat enables Snorlax to reliably switch into Fire-types like Chandelure and Volcanion. 12 HP EVs slightly increase recovery from Leftovers. Snorlax can opt for a spread of 12 HP / 116 Atk / 204 Def / 176 SpD to OHKO Cobalion with Earthquake after a Curse and a Defense drop from Close Combat and evade a 3HKO from Xurkitree's Thunderbolt and Volcanion's Steam Eruption. Alternatively, Snorlax can use a spread of 184 HP / 72 Def / 252 SpD to avoid a 2HKO from Choice Specs Toxtricity's Boomburst after Stealth Rock.

Snorlax usually prefers to be on balanced and bulky offensive teams due to it checking major wallbreakers like Chandelure and its sweeping potential. Snorlax's weakness to Fighting-type attacks means it appreciates having Fairy-types teammates like Galarian Weezing, Gardevoir, and Togekiss. Galarian Weezing is particularly useful for switching into Guts Heracross, which can threaten to OHKO Snorlax even after a Curse. Cleric support from the likes of Sylveon and Umbreon is very helpful if Snorlax is forced out after using Rest. Snorlax enjoys having Toxic Spikes support from Dragalge and Galarian Weezing since it can pressure bulky Waters-types like Haze Milotic. Knock Off users like Incineroar and Obstagoon make great teammates because they are able to remove valuable items like Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers, making it easier for Snorlax to beat its checks such as Haze Milotic and Rhyperior. Snorlax likes to have Dark-type Pokemon such as Zarude and Drapion as teammates since they are able to check Ghost-types like Mimikyu and Doublade.

Crobat.overview: Crobat is among RU's elite Pokemon, with the defensive utility to check common Pokemon like Golisopod, Pangoro, Heracross, and Roserade and the Speed to revenge kill weakened setup sweepers like Mimikyu and Lucario. Crobat is the tier's premier entry hazard removal option, as it checks the Spikes users Roserade, Heracross, and Golisopod, and it's highly practical to fit Defog on a Pokemon with already-good role compression. Crobat possesses many other great support moves like U-turn to support wallbreakers, Super Fang to weaken the likes of Registeel and Rhyperior, Toxic for crippling bulky switch-ins, and Taunt to prevent setup and recovery attempts. Crobat also has an excellent Nasty Plot set that threatens to sweep, and it can turn the tables on typical Steel- and Rock-type counters like Steelix, Registeel, and Rhyperior with boosted Heat Wave and Giga Drain. However, as a Defogger, Crobat has poor matchups against most Stealth Rock setters like Registeel, Steelix, and Metagross. Spikes Klefki is also generally good at taking advantage of teams relying on it. Moreover, Crobat's reliance on Heavy-Duty Boots leaves it vulnerable to Knock Off from Pokemon it checks like Heracross and Golisopod. Nasty Plot Crobat's sweeps can often fall short due to its lack of power. The likes of Metagross, Incineroar, and Registeel can take even boosted attacks and leave it damaged enough for revenge killers like opposing Crobat and Choice Scarf Flygon. Furthermore, Raikou, Xurkitree, and Nidoqueen are common offensive checks that can take a boosted attack and OHKO it.
Crobat.comments:
Other Options

Crobat can run slower, bulkier EV spreads with Toxic or Haze over U-turn on stall and semi-stall teams, which further helps against physical attackers like Heracross, Lucario, and Acrobatics Tornadus. 252 HP / 152 Def / 104 Spe with Jolly outpaces Tornadus and 252 HP / 240 Def / 16 Spe with Jolly outpaces Celebi. Haze helps against setup sweepers like Lucario, Togekiss, Mimikyu, and Calm Mind Reuniclus that opt for Shadow Ball over Psyshock.

Checks and Counters

Steel- and Rock-types: Registeel, Rhyperior, and Steelix can use Crobat to set Stealth Rock, but Super Fang Crobat wears them down and they lose quickly to Nasty Plot sets. Aerodactyl scares out Crobat and can stay healthy throughout a game with Roost, but it struggles to check Crobat if Stealth Rock is up. Dragon Dance Tyrantrum and Aerodactyl use Crobat for easy setup.

Electric-types: Raikou and Xurkitree can switch into pivot Crobat and scare it out, but they get worn quickly by Brave Bird and U-turn. They can also take +2 Sludge Bomb and therefore check Nasty Plot Crobat. Choice Scarf Xurkitree and Rotom-C outspeed and scare out Crobat.

Psychic-types: Calm Mind Reuniclus uses Crobat as an easy setup opportunity and can force out boosted Nasty Plot Crobat. Assault Vest Reuniclus doesn't switch into Brave Bird with entry hazards up comfortably, but it can scare out Crobat and is a great check to Nasty Plot sets. Choice Scarf Gardevoir outpaces and threatens to OHKO Crobat.

Other Poison-resistant Pokemon: Chandelure, Stone Edge Flygon, and Nidoqueen are good checks to Nasty Plot Crobat, though the former two dislike Sludge Bomb poison, and boosted Hurricane quickly beats them all. Choice Scarf Flygon can also have its Stone Edge PP potentially stalled by Roost Crobat.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
U-turn takes advantage of bulky switch-ins for wallbreaking teammates like Lucario. Crobat is a great Defog user because it checks the Spikes users Roserade, Heracross, and Golisopod. Crobat can afford options over Defog if it's on a highly offensive team or the team is packing hazard removal elsewhere. Toxic cripples bulky switch-ins like Umbreon, Milotic, and Rhyperior. Sets with Toxic prefer Infiltrator to hit Suicune behind its Substitute. Taunt can prevent Stealth Rock from Crobat's switch-ins, setup from Pokemon like Dragon Dance Flygon and Nasty Plot Togekiss, and recovery from walls like Milotic and Jellicent. Super Fang is great for weakening Steel- and Rock-type switch-ins like Registeel, Steelix, and Rhyperior. Taunt can be run over U-turn alongside Super Fang or Toxic; this makes Crobat very effective at beating bulky Pokemon like Registeel, Milotic, and Umbreon. The given EV spread outpaces Noivern and grants bulk for checking Heracross and Golisopod. Maximum Attack investment is also viable to make Crobat a better revenge killer, which can be particularly helpful against Lucario and Mimikyu. Inner Focus prevents Incineroar's Intimidate Attack drops and Choice Scarf Togekiss's Air Slash flinching.

Crobat's ability to reliably lure in Steel-types like Registeel and Steelix makes it pair excellently with wallbreakers such as Pangoro, Lucario, Incineroar, and Nidoqueen. Rapid Spin Starmie and Dhelmise can free Crobat from running Defog. Additionally, Starmie appreciates Crobat checking Grass-types such as Roserade, and Dhelmise checks Electric-types like Raikou and Heliolisk. Super Fang Crobat weakening Steel-types like Registeel and Steelix can assist teammates such as Mimikyu and Sharpedo. Bronzong and bulky Water-types like Milotic and Jellicent check Rock-types like Rhyperior and Aerodactyl. Ground-types like Nidoqueen and Flygon cover Crobat's Electric weakness. Grass-types and specially defensive Pokemon like Celebi, Roserade, and Umbreon also help against Electric-types. Rotom-C, Heliolisk, and Xurkitree create a VoltTurn core with Crobat, giving it Defog opportunities against Grass-types like Roserade, while Crobat pivots them in against Pokemon like Rhyperior. Steel-types like Metagross, Registeel, and Escavalier can keep Psychic-types like Choice Scarf Gardevoir in check. Escavalier and Cosmic Power Metagross are also able to check Calm Mind Reuniclus.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Sludge Bomb is the preferred STAB move, as it is perfectly accurate, can cripple checks with poison, and hits Togekiss super effectively. Alternatively, Hurricane hits Poison-resistant Pokemon, with +2 Crobat OHKOing Chandelure immediately and Flygon and Nidoqueen with minimal prior damage. Heat Wave hits Steel-types like Metagross and Registeel. Boosted Giga Drain OHKOes Seismitoad and Gastrodon, OHKOes Rhyperior with minimal damage, and 2HKOes Jellicent. If the team can cripple Grass-weak Pokemon via Knock Off or Toxic, Crobat can more afford the longevity of Roost, allowing it to accrue multiple boosts in the face of Registeel and Umbreon. Roost is also more justifiable alongside Hurricane, since boosted Hurricane hits Giga Drain targets like Jellicent, Gastrodon, and Seismitoad hard. Inner Focus prevents Choice Scarf Togekiss's Air Slash flinching.

Xurkitree, Rotom-C, and Heliolisk can pivot on Grass-types like Roserade and Dhelmise for Crobat to set up Nasty Plot on. Ground-types like Nidoqueen, Steelix, and Flygon cover Crobat's Electric weakness. Grass-types and specially defensive Pokemon like Celebi, Roserade, and Registeel can also help check Electric-types. Nasty Plot Crobat weakening Steel-types like Registeel helps Pokemon like Mimikyu, Goodra, and Sharpedo, and they can weaken Steel-types themselves for Crobat. Dark- and Steel-types like Incineroar, Cosmic Power Metagross, and Escavalier check Reuniclus and Choice Scarf Gardevoir, though nearly any Steel-type is a good Gardevoir check. Crobat can double up with other Flying-types like Togekiss, Tornadus, and Sigilyph to exploit shared checks like Registeel, Raikou, and Rhyperior. Incineroar and Salazzle can cripple Water- and Rock-types with Knock Off or Toxic for non-Giga Drain Crobat, and Incineroar can outright take advantage of Jellicent. Toxic Rhyperior and Metagross are also good for crippling Water-types.

Xatu.overview: Xatu's decent bulk, typing, and Magic Bounce allow it to neutralize common entry hazard setters in RU such as Steelix, Registeel, and Metagross without having to waste a turn using Defog. This, coupled with its ability to consistently pivot with Teleport, makes it a solid choice on offense teams. Still, even with maximum investment, Xatu's bulk is less than stellar. This can make it inconsistent against some hazard setters; for example, Metagross can 2HKO Xatu with a Meteor Mash Attack boost. Thus, Xatu may need to stay near full health to effectively perform its role. It can be risky to use Teleport, and Xatu depends on good predictions to keep hazards off the field. Xatu is also unable to beat certain setters like Stakataka, Golisopod, and Rhyperior, which considerably reduces its effectiveness.
Xatu.comments:
Other Options

U-turn provides fast pivoting, although it's generally outclassed by Teleport's slow pivoting and synergy with Future Sight. Heavy-Duty Boots preserves Xatu's pivoting abilities in matchups where it fails to prevent Stealth Rock from going up, but losing Rocky Helmet can be detrimental against Stealth Rock setters like Metagross and Registeel. Thunder Wave can support slower wallbreakers such as Pangoro. Air Slash hits Pangoro, Roserade, and Golisopod in one attack, although it's weak. Calm Mind over Teleport could transform Xatu into a threat against slower teams, though losing Teleport is certainly not ideal.

Checks and Counters

Specific Entry Hazard Setters: Golisopod can remove Rocky Helmet with Knock Off and click Liquidation until it gets a Defense drop, forcing Xatu out and letting it set Spikes. Rhyperior will always beat non-Grass Knot Xatu. A healthy Stakataka will beat Xatu one-on-one. Roserade can't stay in on Future Sight but takes advantage of Xatu's weak Special Defense with Sludge Bomb.

Dark-types: Dark-types like Incineroar and Pangoro can either set up on Xatu or force it out to threaten potential switch-ins, and they can easily put a stop to Future Sight.

Electric-types: Raikou and Xurkitree can easily switch into Xatu and maintain momentum with Volt Switch.

Ghost-types: As Xatu finds itself on mostly offense teams, Ghost-types like Golurk, Dhelmise, and Decidueye can pressure it with Poltergeist or force a sack. However, this risk can be mitigated by going itemless.

sets.name: Magic Bounce
sets.description:
Future Sight pressures the opposing team and creates opportunities for Xatu to safely pivot into a wallbreaker with Teleport. Alternatively, Grass Knot hits Rhyperior for significant damage;(comma to semicolon) however, it makes Xatu significantly more passive and reliant on Teleport to be effective. The combination of Heat Wave and Rocky Helmet allows Xatu to consistently block Steel-types such as Registeel, Bronzong, and Steelix from setting entry hazards. 16 Speed EVs let it outspeed Golurk, and investment in Defense allows Xatu to outlast Metagross with Rocky Helmet. Not running an item is feasible to avoid Poltergeist from Ghost-type wallbreakers like Golurk and Dhelmise, as well as reducing Knock Off damage from Pokemon like Golisopod, at the cost of effectiveness against most hazard setters. 60 Special Attack EVs allow Xatu to OHKO Nidoqueen with Future Sight after Stealth Rock but weakens the Metagross matchup.

Xatu can weaken passive bulky Pokemon like Registeel by stalling them out, making sweepers like Sharpedo and Mimikyu significantly more reliable. Similarly, Pokemon with a vulnerability to Steel-types, such as Roserade and Gardevoir, can capitalize on this. These Pokemon can also take advantage of Teleport to safely set up. Entry hazard-weak Pokemon such as Tornadus and weather sweepers can forgo running Heavy-Duty Boots with Xatu, opening up teambuilding possibilities with other sets. Other pivots such as Flygon, Incineroar, Rotom-C, and Xurkitree can form a VoltTurn core with Xatu. Extra hazard removal from Flygon and Starmie can mitigate Xatu's inability to prevent entry hazards from certain setters. Volt Switch users like Raikou and Cobalion can capitalize on Xatu's weak Special Defense and Electric weakness, making Ground-types like Nidoqueen and Flygon great partners. They can also take advantage of any Rock-types Xatu forces in with Teleport. Wallbreakers like Bewear appreciate Teleport and can use it to capitalize on a setup opportunity.

sets.name: Rain Setter
sets.description:
Politoed enables a powerful but matchup-reliant archetype in rain due to being the only Drizzle Pokemon in the tier. However, outside of setting rain, Politoed is a generally underwhelming Pokemon that cant provide much help to rain teams itself and often becomes a momentum sink due to its passiveness. Encore allows it to deal with bulkier threats that would wall it otherwise and discourage Pokemon from setting up on it. Toxic can break down walls in tandem with Encore, particularly bulky Water-types that pose a threat to rain teams like Milotic. Hypnosis trades some effectiveness against passive builds for the potential to shut down common roadblocks to rain teams like Gastrodon and Assault Vest Reuniclus, and maintain utility against more offensive teams looking to take advantage of Politoeds passivity. Ice Beam chips Grass-types like Celebi, 3HKOes Dragalge, and OHKOes Noivern with the Special Attack investment. Perish Song forces bulky setup sweepers out, allowing Politoed to check Pokemon like Suicune, Snorlax, and Reuniclus. Finally, Rest allows Politoed to continue setting rain when severely weakened and in long matches against passive teams. Non-Ice Beam variants can invest the 76 Special Attack EVs into Defense, as they do nothing significant with Scald. 56 Speed EVs let Politoed outrun Alolan Marowak, but 92 Speed EVs can be ran for Milotic, which Encore + Toxic variants can beat.

Politoeds only niche is setting rain, so Pokemon that take advantage of it are necessary. Swift Swim Pokemon like Kingdra, Ludicolo, and Kabutops can offensively pressure the opponent and sweep once they are weakened. Electric-types of your own like Raikou and Heliolisk are able to run Thunder and Weather Ball as coverage and check Electric- or Water-types. Tornadus also enjoys fully accurate Hurricane and Weather Ball coverage. Toxicroak appreciates the Dry Skin recovery and can switch into Milotic with impunity. Steel-types like Metagross and Steelix can provide good defensive utility for rain teams and appreciate Fire-type moves being weakened under rain. Finally, entry hazard setters such as Klefki and Roserade can help pressure bulkier cores that threaten rain such as Suicune + Assault Vest Reuniclus, as well as synergizing with the surprising amount of switches Politoed can force from defensive Pokemon.

sets.name: Unaware Wall
sets.description:
Quagsire is a reliable wall thanks to its typing and access to Unaware, as it can deal with many physical threats and setup sweepers including Mimikyu, Flygon, and Cloyster. Since it has Unaware, it can afford to be passive and purely focus on not getting KOed, which is different from the playstyles of other bulky Water-types like Gastrodon and Milotic. Toxic hits Flying-types and other walls such as Togekiss or Porygon2, ensuring they do not take advantage of Quagisre's lack of offensive presence. Scald is used to threaten Pokemon such as Steelix and Bronzong and attempt to burn physical attackers such as Mimikyu, Flygon, and Cloyster. Despite being immune to stat changes itself, Quagsire can run Haze in order to beat Stored Power Reuniclus, which can otherwise set up and beat Quagsire one-on-one. Ice Beam can also be run in order to give Grass-types such as Celebi and Roserade a harder time switching in. Curse can be used to turn Quagsire into a late-game sweeper; however, it often struggles due to how vulnerable it is to special attacks. Heavy-Duty Boots are used to ensure entry hazards do not cripple it, which is often crucial since Quagsire's natural bulk isn't good enough to take multiple hits at lower percents. Running Haze over Toxic can also be effective, as Toxic isn't often necessary against what Quagsire checks.

Quagsire is primarily used on stall teams because it allows them to not be overwhelmed by setup sweepers. Umbreon is a great partner for Quagsire, as it can tank the special hits that it can't, such as Toxtricity's Boomburst or Chandelure's Shadow Ball. Umbreon also often runs Heal Bell, which helps Quagsire clear any status it might receive from the likes of Metagross, Bronzong, or Raikou. Due to Quagsire's middling bulk, it often cannot deal with stronger wallbreakers of the tier such as Bewear and Guts Heracross; Galarian Weezing is a great choice of teammate, as it can wall these threats. Lucario and Pangoro can both 2HKO Quagsire with Close Combat, so having a Flying-type such as Crobat, Talonflame, or Xatu on the team to eliminate this weakness is helpful. Flying-types also help Quagsire by dealing with Grass-types such as Roserade and Celebi. Registeel also makes for a great partner as it too can wall the aforementioned Grass-types.

Umbreon.overview: Umbreon's high special bulk and defensive typing make it a great check for common special threats such as Xurkitree, Chandelure, and Nidoqueen. Wish and Heal Bell enable it to stay healthy over the course of the battle and support its teammates. Foul Play allows Umbreon to better deal with various threats such as Golurk, Flygon, and Nasty Plot Celebi, while its ability Synchronize makes it difficult for Pokemon such as Raikou, Gastrodon, and Milotic to weaken it with status moves. However, Umbreon's weaknesses to Fighting and Fairy leave it vulnerable to common threats such as Lucario, Heracross, and Gardevoir. In addition, its passive nature, increased by its two-turn recovery, makes it easy for many Pokemon such as Reuniclus, Togekiss, and the aforementioned Lucario to take advantage of it.
Umbreon.comments:
Other Options

Moonlight instead of either Protect, Wish, or Heal Bell gives Umbreon a one-turn recovery, but it does not have many PP and supporting teammates is one of the main reasons to use Umbreon. A physically defensive set can better check threats such as Metagross, Flygon, and Golisopod. However, many teams prefer the specially defensive variant, since it counters more important Pokemon. 180 EVs can be invested into Speed to outspeed Adamant Golurk. However, this makes Umbreon worse against special attackers such Nidoqueen and Chandelure. Inner Focus with Toxic is an option to better deal with Togekiss, but it has less use outside of this matchup.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types and Fighting-type Coverage: Pokemon like Bewear and Pangoro can take huge advantage of Umbreon, but they dislike Toxic. Heracross, Lucario, and Toxicroak take good damage from Foul Play but pressure Umbreon with their Fighting-type moves. Stakataka, Reuniclus, and Sharpedo often run Fighting-type coverage that can break through Umbreon.

Fairy-types: Barring sets with Toxic, Togekiss and Diancie easily set up on Umbreon. Klefki has nothing to fear from Umbreon, can set up Spikes freely, and pressures it with Toxic. Mimikyu can safely set up once due to Disguise and OHKO Umbreon with a boosted Play Rough. Although Gardevoir takes good damage from Foul Play, it 2HKOes Umbreon with Moonblast.

Bulky Setup Sweepers: Calm Mind Suicune, Reuniclus, and Curse Snorlax easily use Umbreon as setup fodder, since they take little from Foul Play and negate Toxic through Magic Guard, Rest, or Substitute.

Physical Attackers: Strong physical attackers such as Choice Band Flygon and Metagross overwhelm or break through Umbreon, but most of them take a lot from Foul Play.

Taunt and Trick: Taunt and Trick users such as Noivern, Crobat, Gardevoir, and Chandelure restrict Umbreon to one move, allowing them to better deal with it.

Toxic-immune Pokemon: Pokemon that are immune to Toxic such as Registeel, Nidoqueen, and Steelix cripple Umbreon with their own Toxic and cannot be statused in return.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Foul Play hits many physical attackers that try to take advantage of Umbreon such as Metagross, Golurk, and Flygon. Protect enables Umbreon to heal from Wish safely and scout Choice-locked Pokemon such as Gardevoir, Chandelure, and Heracross. If the team already has a cleric, Toxic is a good option over Heal Bell to punish common counters such as Togekiss, Incineroar, and Suicune. Since Umbreon is affected by every entry hazard, Heavy-Duty Boots gives it more switch-in opportunities and makes it less dependent on entry hazard control. Alternatively, Leftovers is a good choice for some passive recovery if the team has reliable entry hazard control.

Balance, semi-stall, and stall teams appreciate Umbreon's defensive qualities to check threatening Pokemon such as Polteageist, Chandelure, and Nidoqueen. Defensive Pokemon without reliable recovery such as Registeel, Stakataka, Bronzong, and Diancie appreciate Umbreon's Wish support. In return, they check Togekiss and either check troublesome Fairy-types or take the role of cleric to relieve Umbreon. Since Fighting-types such as Heracross, Bewear, and Pangoro heavily pressure Umbreon, checks to them such as Crobat, Dhelmise, and Galarian Weezing are very important. These Pokemon also give reliable entry hazard control if Umbreon runs Leftovers. On more defensive teams, Quagsire is a good choice to keep setup sweepers such as Reuniclus, Lucario, and Suicune in check, while Choice Scarf Ditto is a reliable offensive check to them. Reuniclus and Suicune are great setup sweepers on more semi-stalling teams and appreciate Umbreon's ability to check Ghost-types and keep them healthy with Heal Bell and Wish. Physical walls such as Gastrodon, Vileplume, and Galarian Weezing check troublesome physical threats such as Pangoro, Stakataka, and Sharpedo, which can overwhelm Umbreon.

Steelix.overview: Steelix's natural bulk, defensive typing, and multiple utility options make it an excellent Stealth Rock setter for balanced or bulky offensive teams. Its solid typing blocks Volt Switch from common Electric-types while also packing a Grass neutrality to check Xurkitree and Heliolisk, qualities only it and Nidoqueen offer as Stealth Rock users. Additionally, it serves as a check to common threats like Xurkitree, Mimikyu, Registeel, and Metagross. However, some Electric- and Fairy-types, such as Raikou and Togekiss, commonly carry coverage moves that Steelix is vulnerable to. Steelix also struggles with common Water-types like Gastrodon, Milotic, and Jellicent, and its Grass neutrality makes it a Steel-type that cannot reliably check threats like Roserade.
Steelix.comments:
Other Options

Iron Defense + Body Press can handle threats like Curse Snorlax reliably. However, another move must be sacrificed for Iron Defense, and dropping Earthquake leaves Steelix worse off against Electric-types. Dragon Tail or Roar could be thrown in for setup sweepers like Curse Gastrodon, Reuniclus, and Suicune. Unfortunately, the moves force Steelix to move last, so it can end up getting KOed by Scald or Focus Blast.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Milotic, Gastrodon, and Suicune barely take any damage from Steelix's moves and only worry about Toxic, which Suicune can cure with Rest.

Ground-types: Nidoqueen and Rhyperior offensively pressure Steelix. They don't want to be hit with Earthquake or Toxic, however.

Fighting-types: Pangoro and Heracross can pick off weakened Steelix with Close Combat.

Bulky Setup Sweepers: Magic Guard Reuniclus, Suicune, and Snorlax don't mind switching into Toxic and freely set up on Steelix.

Fire-types: Chandelure, Salazzle, and Darmanitan force Steelix out with ease. They need to beware of Earthquake from Sturdy variants, however.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Heavy Slam lets Steelix immediately threaten Fairy-types, OHKOing Gardevoir and Mimikyu, and 2HKOing Togekiss. Toxic puts common switch-ins to Steelix, like Milotic and Bewear, under pressure. The last moveslot is fairly flexible. Body Press, for example, allows Steelix to potentially 2HKO Umbreon and OHKO Pangoro. Head Smash coupled with Rock Head can catch Crobat and Noivern off guard and force them to use Roost.

Steelix is forced out by numerous threats, including Ground-types like Rhyperior and Flygon. Because of this, teammates like Milotic and Gastrodon are appreciated. Common Water-types like Milotic, Gastrodon, and Suicune force Steelix out or cripple it. Xurkitree, Raikou,and Roserade work as answers to them. Roserade can also provide Spikes support, put more pressure on Togekiss, and check Raikou, while Xurkitree can threaten other Ground-types with Energy Ball. Fire-types like Chandelure and Entei also offensively pressure Steelix, so partners like Incineroar and Noivern are greatly appreciated. Fighting-types like Heracross and Pangoro appreciate Steelix checking Fairy-types that they struggle with. Fairy-type partners like Togekiss and Galarian Weezing are appreciated, since they check Fighting-types. A teammate like Crobat or Tornadus can scare off Grass-types like Celebi and Roserade, which Steelix is not a reliable switch-in or check to.

Heracross.overview: Heracross stands out as one of the strongest dedicated wallbreakers in the tier thanks to its powerful STAB options supported by its high Attack and solid Speed tier. Its great abilities in Guts and Moxie can further crank up its power, and it takes advantage of prominent defensive Dark- and Steel-types such as Incineroar, Umbreon, and Registeel. Heracross is also capable of sweeping and cleaning with a Choice Scarf set and Moxie. However, Heracross has nearly no defensive utility and lacks any longevity, so it sometimes struggles to come in safely and make use of its strength. Pokemon such as Crobat, Talonflame, and Mimikyu can switch in on a resisted attack and stave it off, and it's fairly easy to revenge kill with common Pokemon.
Heracross.comments:
Other Options

Heracross can make use of Focus Sash as a Spikes setter on specific hyper offense teams. Heracross can also make use of Choice Band, using the same set as the Choice Scarf set but replacing Moxie with Guts, and play like the Guts set with greater longevity while potentially getting an extra Attack boost from switching into a stray Toxic. Guts can also be run on the Choice Scarf set to soak status such as a Scald burn from Gastrodon or a Toxic from Umbreon.

Checks and Counters

Flying-types Flying-types such as Togekiss, Noivern, Talonflame, and Crobat can switch into Heracross's STAB moves and force it out, and most have the bulk to survive one Stone Edge from the Choice Scarf set, allowing them to serve as solid checks to it.

Faster Revenge Killers Faster Pokemon such as Noivern, Crobat, Talonflame, and Tornadus can force Heracross out and KO it with their STAB moves. Multiple unboosted Pokemon on offense teams routinely pressure Flame Orb Heracross, since Heracross is not particularly fast without Choice Scarf.

Residual Damage Wearing Flame Orb Heracross down via entry hazards, burn damage, and pivoting around it with Pokemon like Cobalion, Crobat, and Vileplume can stave it off.

Galarian Weezing Galarian Weezing is capable of switching into all Heracross variants throughout a game and forcing it out, and it can remove Heracross's Spikes with Defog. Neutralizing Gas even makes Flame Orb decrease Heracross's Attack instead of raising it with Guts. It is the single best counter to Heracross in the tier, though it is not a very prominent Pokemon overall.

sets.name: Flame Orb
sets.description:
Heracross is fantastic at nuking bulky Dark- and Steel-types such as Incineroar, Umbreon, and Registeel, as well as Normal-types like Snorlax and Porygon2, with Close Combat. Megahorn lets Heracross cleave through Grass- and Psychic-types such as Vileplume, Celebi, and Reuniclus, which can normally take on most other Fighting-types. Facade is great at thrashing the Flying-types of the tier in Togekiss, Crobat, and Noivern on the switch, as well as being a safe option if you don't want to deal with Close Combat dropping defenses or Megahorn's accuracy. Knock Off hits Ghost-types such as Chandelure, Golurk, and Mimikyu while being great at crippling Pokemon such as Togekiss, Crobat, and Galarian Weezing. Stone Edge is an alternative option over Facade if you wish for a hard OHKO on the aforementioned Flying-types; however, Facade does enough to where this generally isn't necessary.

Heracross favors being on more offensive teams, which grant it more opportunities to break through the opposition. Heracross pairs very well with Volt Switch users such as Raikou and Xurkitree, which invite in the Grass-types that it preys on while covering its Flying weakness. Similarly, Crobat allows Heracross entry on the Steel-types that switch into it safely with U-turn. Bulky Water-types such as Milotic can respond to Fire-types such as Salazzle and Entei, which force out Heracross, while providing entry points for it thanks to Flip Turn. Pokemon such as Starmie, Flygon, and the aforementioned Crobat help Heracross stick around by clearing entry hazards and provide the momentum it adores. Starmie in particular is a great partner thanks to Rapid Spin keeping your hazards up, helping Heracross grab more KOs throughout the game, which Dhelmise can also provide. Setters such as Stakataka and Diancie can provide these hazards Heracross loves while checking Pokemon that give it trouble such as Togekiss and Crobat. Grass-types that can cripple Flying-types such as Stun Spore Roserade and Thunder Wave Celebi are also good partners.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Heracross's solid Speed, good power, Moxie, and Choice Scarf lend themselves to great revenge killing. Close Combat can now pick off faster Pokemon such as Heliolisk and Raikou. Megahorn rams through Pokemon such as Gardevoir, Roserade, and Celebi. Knock Off provides a response to Ghost-types such as Choice Scarf Chandelure, and it removes the Heavy-Duty Boots of the aforementioned Flying-types in Togekiss and Crobat, which Heracross's teammates can capitalize on. Stone Edge can be used to more reliably KO the Flying-types while still hitting the most relevant Ghost-types in the tier. Spikes can be used over either coverage move, providing additional utility and pressure on forced switches against Pokemon Heracross can't immediately threaten. Knock Off is generally preferred on bulky offense teams that appreciate the long-term benefits of removing Heavy-Duty Boots from the Flying-types, while offense appreciates the immediate smack of Stone Edge. Spikes is a great alternative on both styles of teams if both coverage moves aren't required, providing opportunities for Heracross to clean late-game with Moxie boosts.

Pokemon that benefit from Knock Off crippling Flying-types such as Celebi and Roserade are great partners. Roserade may also handle setting Spikes for Heracross or vice versa, depending on team preference. Pokemon that can bring Heracross in safely on Grass-types such as Raikou and Xurkitree are great partners, and they additionally handle the Flying-types that give Heracross trouble. Spinners such as Starmie and Dhelmise work well for entry hazard removal, since Heracross greatly appreciates its own team's entry hazards staying up. Pokemon that can switch into faster Choice Scarf users like Flygon, such as Milotic and Gastrodon, are good partners. Finally, hazard setters that can keep hazards up against Flying-types such as Diancie, Stakataka, and Metagross support it well.

sets.name: Rain Sweeper
sets.description:
Kingdra's all-around good stats and access to Swift Swim make it an excellent choice on rain teams. Hurricane is used so that Kingdra can beat Grass-type Pokemon like Roserade without Draco Meteor Special Attack drops. Hydro Pump's main use over the more accurate Surf is to 2HKO even dedicated special walls like Registeel, Umbreon, and Assault Vest Reuniclus in rain; Surf is already powerful enough to OHKO most offensive Pokemon it hits neutrally. Flip Turn can be used instead to grab momentum off of Kingdra's checks and ease prediction for Choice Specs sets. Life Orb is the preferred item because it boosts power without locking Kingdra into one move; however, Choice Specs gives Kingdra the best chance to 2HKO bulky Water-types like Suicune and Milotic with Draco Meteor while also avoiding Life Orb's chip damage. Kingdra can opt for a Timid nature in order to outpace Choice Specs Gardevoir, which copies its Swift Swim with Trace, and improve its matchups against the likes of Togekiss and Chandelure out of rain.

Kingdra must always be supported by Drizzle from Politoed to activate Swift Swim. Without Drizzle support, Kingdra is outclassed by other offensive Water-type Pokemon like Starmie. Kingdra works best when used alongside other rain sweepers. Kabutops, Omastar, and Ludicolo can weaken bulky Water-type Pokemon like Milotic and Suicune. Toxicroak walls the aforementioned bulky Water-types and can also switch into First Impression attempts from Golisopod, making it an especially good Kingdra partner. In a similar vein, Tornadus benefits from Kingdra's Flip Turn to come in safely and break down bulky Water-type Pokemon.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Porygon2 can function decently as a defensive pivot thanks to its great support movepool, Eviolite-boosted bulk, and amazing ability. Teleport allows Porygon2 to reliably get in powerful wallbreakers while sparing them from taking direct damage. Ice Beam is generally the preferred attacking move because it OHKOes Noivern and Flygon, while also 2HKOing Roserade and Golurk. Tri Attack is a decent alternative that does more to the likes of Xurkitree, Raikou, and Starmie. Toxic cripples the likes of Milotic, Rhyperior, and Raikou, mitigating their long-term impact against Porygon2's teammates. Foul Play is an attacking option to hit Metagross and Alolan Marowak, while also letting Porygon2 check Polteageist much easier. A specially defensive spread allows Eviolite Porygon2 to blanket check many dangerous special attackers, such as Xurkitree, Toxtricity, and Roserade. Some Defense investment can be used to make Porygon2 a better pivot into the likes of Dhelmise and Flygon should its team need it. Trace allows Porygon2 to copy great abilities, like Regenerator from Reuniclus and Punk Rock from Toxtricity.

Porygon2 pairs very well with most offensive Pokemon, as it's able to absorb damage and switch them in safely with Teleport. Toxtricity, Pangoro, Golurk, and Heracross are powerful wallbreakers that enjoy having Porygon2 to fall back on when they're forced out by certain special attackers, such as Noivern. Pokemon such as Dhelmise and Starmie can remove entry hazards, which otherwise hamper Porygon2's ability to pivot and forces it to use Recover more often. A pivoting core can also be powerful, especially with the likes of Flygon, Incineroar, and Raikou, as it can keep Porygon2 in favorable situations. Powerful Fighting-types such as Heracross, Pangoro, and Lucario can take advantage of Porygon2's inability to generally threaten them. The aforementioned Togekiss and Galarian Weezing fare well against Heracross and Pangoro, while Jellicent can handle Lucario. In turn, Porygon2 can easily handle most Toxtricity variants and other Electric types. Togekiss can even provide Defog and Heal Bell support, while Galarian Weezing can handle most Knock Off users.

Raikou.overview: Raikou is a solid offensive pivot thanks to its high Speed outrunning other threats like Heracross and Tornadus, which is its main advantage over fellow Electric-types like Xurkitree and Toxtricity. Heavy-Duty Boots makes it difficult to wear down passively, letting it use Volt Switch with great freedom, and its useful coverage across Shadow Ball, Extrasensory, and Scald keeps many Pokemon from confidently switching into it. It can put that coverage to even greater use with its Calm Mind wallbreaking set. Its biggest problem is its glaring inability to hit Gastrodon and Flygon very hard; the best it can do is use Toxic or try to burn Flygon with Scald, so they hold it off well early-game. Its attacks are generally a bit weak, so it often relies on teammates to actually break through bulky Pokemon like Registeel and Assault Vest Reuniclus, and its defensive typing isn't good for much beyond switching into Togekiss and Xurkitree; this means it's hesitant to take strong attacks. The Calm Mind set sacrifices Volt Switch, making it a worse team player and thus harder to fit. Stronger Electric-types like Xurkitree and Toxtricity are much better than pivot Raikou at breaking through cores by themselves, while others like Heliolisk and Rotom-Mow offer greater defensive utility due to their typings and abilities.
Raikou.comments:
Other Options

Substitute + Calm Mind punishes passive defensive cores but lacks room for coverage. Aura Sphere on pivot Raikou puts the most pressure on Steel-types like Stakataka and Registeel; their low Speed and Volt Switch vulnerability make this less important on average. Weather Ball makes Raikou a much bigger threat on weather teams; hail gives it the excellent combination of Electric and Ice, rain gives it stronger Water-type coverage, and sun lets it hit Steel- and Grass-types with a single move.

Checks and Counters

Certain Ground-types: Ground-types that aren't weak to Scald are the safest early-game switch-ins to Raikou. Gastrodon has Recover and Storm Drain, making it near insurmountable for Raikou even when badly poisoned. Quagsire also has Recover while handling coverage moves well, and Choice Scarf Flygon can immediately force Raikou out but fears Scald burns.

Special Walls: Pokemon with a lot of special bulk, including Assault Vest Reuniclus, Registeel, Snorlax, and Umbreon, can take Raikou's attacks for a long time and immediately hinder it in return with Toxic or a strong attack. Pivot Raikou can just use Volt Switch the turn after they switch in, though.

Grass-types: If Raikou lacks Extrasensory, Roserade, and Vileplume are good switch-ins to it, and if it lacks Shadow Ball, Celebi, Dhelmise, and Decidueye handle its attacks well. Decidueye and Dhelmise want to avoid Scald burns, however.

Revenge Killers: Raikou's average bulk and lack of resistances make it easy for most faster Pokemon to take out once weakened. Physical Choice Scarf users such as Flygon and Heracross deal massive damage. Noivern and Salazzle are faster but struggle against Calm Mind boosts. Golisopod's First Impression also does the trick.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description:
Volt Switch and Thunderbolt are staples for Electric-type pivots. Scald covers most Ground-types, threatening to burn Flygon and being super effective on Nidoqueen, Golurk, and Steelix. Toxic is the only way for Raikou to significantly impact Gastrodon switch-ins; if teammates can hit Gastrodon with Toxic or Knock Off, the last moveslot can be Extrasensory or Shadow Ball for specific Grass-type checks like Roserade and Celebi. Inner Focus prevents flinches from Choice Scarf Togekiss's Air Slash.

Raikou is a self-sufficient pivot that covers Togekiss and creates openings for all sorts of wallbreaker teammates. Grass-types like Roserade and Celebi cover Gastrodon, Raikou's biggest problems. A switch-in to Choice Scarf Flygon like Togekiss, Bronzong, or Vileplume will often help, though any Ground-immune Pokemon goes a long way in limiting it. Psychic-types like Reuniclus and Gardevoir can take advantage of non-Extrasensory Raikou's Poison-type switch-ins, Roserade and Toxtricity.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Calm Mind Raikou can surprise those expecting the pivot set and break through weakened cores. Scald covers most Ground-types, threatening to burn Flygon and being super effective on Nidoqueen, Golurk, and Steelix. Shadow Ball covers Celebi, which is near impossible to break through otherwise, while Aura Sphere pressures Registeel and Umbreon, resilient special walls. Leftovers creates more chances to boost, but Heavy-Duty Boots can save Raikou more HP short term if your team lacks entry hazard control and fears Stealth Rock + Spikes. Inner Focus stops flinches from Choice Scarf Togekiss's Air Slash.

Calm Mind Raikou needs more support than its pivot set given its lack of Volt Switch and preference to avoid early damage. Physical wallbreakers like Heracross and Swords Dance Incineroar pressure special walls, and Grass-types cover Gastrodon. Steel-types like Metagross and Stakataka work as extra answers to Flying-types and can use Toxic on Gastrodon switching in. Entry hazard removers like Crobat, Starmie, and Dhelmise help Leftovers sets accrue enough HP to be worthwhile.

Entei.overview: Choice Band Entei is a solid wallbreaker that punishes conventional Fire-type answers such as Flygon, Diancie, and Suicune with a burn from Sacred Fire. Furthermore, Entei can act as a revenge killer with Extreme Speed, letting it pick off many dangerous sweepers like Cloyster, Flygon, and Sharpedo. Entei also has a great Speed tier for a wallbreaker and outspeeds key offensive threats such as Mimikyu, Obstagoon, and Xurkitree. The team compression provided by being both a wallbreaker and revenge killer, as well as sporting great natural bulk and a key Speed tier, makes it particularly sought after on sun teams. Under sun, Entei's counterplay dwindles, as once hard stops like Gastrodon, Quagsire, and Snorlax have a high chance of getting 2HKOed by sun-boosted Flare Blitz after Stealth Rock and burn. However, Entei's Stealth Rock weakness severely limits it, especially on sun teams, which generally lacks thorough entry hazard removal. Outside of sun teams, Entei faces far harsher competition from other wallbreakers, especially Darmanitan, which can afford to run Heavy-Duty Boots, is about as strong as Choice Band Entei, and can keep up momentum with U-turn.
Entei.comments:
Other Options

Heavy-Duty Boots may seem tempting, but the loss of power compared to Choice Band is rarely worth it and makes it even harder to justify using Entei over Darmanitan. Similar to Suicune, Entei can attempt to run a Calm Mind + Substitute set, but such a set can't touch Chandelure, has few switch-in opportunities, retains Entei's Stealth Rock weakness, and still struggles with Water-types, especially Haze Milotic.

Checks and Counters

Bulky Water-types: Bulky Water-types such as Milotic, Gastrodon, and Quagsire can switch into any attack and heal off burn damage with Recover; however, the latter two need to watch out if they're burned, as they have a high chance of getting 2HKOed by sun-boosted Flare Blitz after Stealth Rock. Suicune can also take any hit from Entei, but it doesn't enjoy a potential burn.

Entry Hazards: In general, Entei is at the full mercy of entry hazards, especially Stealth Rock and Spikes, as it cannot afford to use Heavy-Duty Boots.

Faster Threats: Entei will rarely be at full health, which leaves it vulnerable to be revenge killed by faster threats like Noivern, Starmie, and Raikou.

Snorlax: While not the most common, Snorlax completely counters Entei thanks to Thick Fat and Rest. However, sun-boosted Flare Blitz has a near-guaranteed chance to 2HKO Snorlax after Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Extreme Speed is what truly differentiates Entei from the other Fire-types. Stone Edge hits Fire-types such as Incineroar, Volcanion, and Chandelure, as well as Noivern. Flare Blitz is much stronger than Sacred Fire and is a must on sun teams, as it has a good chance to 2HKO a burned Gastrodon or Quagsire after Stealth Rock in the sun. On non-sun teams, Iron Head is a viable option to OHKO Diancie; while it despises a burn from Sacred Fire, Diancie can easily switch into Entei and set Stealth Rock. Toxic is also an option to cripple bulky Water-types such as Milotic, Gastrodon, and Suicune, but with Sacred Fire's 50% burn rate, it can become useless if not played carefully. Inner Focus blocks Intimidate from Incineroar, so it can't switch into Entei's Fire-type attacks in sun.

The playstyle that takes full advantage of Entei's strengths and plays to its full potential are sun teams. Torkoal sets Stealth Rock, sun with Drought, and can remove entry hazards with Rapid Spin. On sun teams, Entei can either work as the team's sole wallbreaker or be run alongside others like Charizard and Heliolisk and act primarily as a revenge killer. Entei lures bulky Water-types such as Gastrodon and Milotic and forces them to use Recover, which can be exploited by Shiftry to get an opportunity to use Growth or a huge hit off. Choice Scarf Gardevoir provides Healing Wish support to heal up Entei after taking many rounds of Stealth Rock damage or attacks from the likes of Togekiss, Mimikyu, and Crobat. On non-sun teams, Entei needs more support to break past bulky Water-types. Assault Vest Reuniclus's Future Sight and lures to Water-types like mixed Metagross and offensive Starmie are effective ways of weakening or getting rid of Gastrodon and Milotic. Pokemon such as Raikou, Flygon, and Stakataka can cripple Gastrodon, Suicune, and Quagsire with Toxic, which greatly aids Entei. Entry hazard removal from Pokemon such as Crobat, Flygon, and Starmie give Entei as many opportunities to wallbreak as possible. They also can provide free switches for Entei with either U-turn or Teleport.

Suicune.overview: The following analysis is outdated. Information contained in the analysis may be misinformative in regards to the current SS RU metagame.

sets.name: Substitute + Calm Mind
sets.description:
Subtitute + Calm Mind Suicune relies on Pressure to wage a war of attrition on a number of Pokemon that can wall it such as Seismitoad, Gastrodon, and Mantine. Calm Mind makes it very hard for special attackers to break Suicune's Substitute and makes Scald much harder to switch into. Substitute provides Suicune with a way to protect itself from status effects, which will cripple sets lacking Rest, and is especially effective for PP stalling Pokemon unable to break its substitute in one hit. Note that Suicune must still be cautious not to switch into status moves like Toxic and Thunder Wave from the likes of Registeel, Togekiss, and Klefki. Protect enables Suicune to scout Choice item users, stall out low PP moves, and gain additional Leftovers recovery. Ice Beam can be used to hit the likes of Zarude and Seismitoad after boosting, which are otherwise major threats. Roar is another option that allows Suicune to phaze out other setup sweepers and rack up entry hazard damage. The EV spread allows Suicune to outpace base 80 Speed Pokemon like Chandelure and Togekiss, while giving it an 81% chance that Seismitoad's Earthquake will not break its Substitute. An alternative spread with maximum Speed will allow Suicune to Speed tie with Heracross, but lowers its chances of its Substitute surviving Seismitoad's Earthquake to about 56%.
