Alternatively, Spirit Shackle is a decent option with Knock Off support to pressure Flying-types such as Togekiss, in addition to giving free momentum. Brave Bird hits Grass-types harder, having a chance to OHKO Vileplume after minimal chip damage and OHKOes Bewear from full health, but recoil damage can be a problem. Long Reach lets Decidueye use U-turn without fearing Rocky Helmet damage. Adamant is used to always OHKO Noivern, Calm Mind Reuniclus, and Polteageist after Stealth Rock.

Raikou and Darmanitan give Decidueye free switches to wallbreak, luring in and pivoting against Pokemon such as Celebi and Milotic. Other VoltTurn partners such as Noivern, Incineroar, and Flygon also make good teammates, as Decidueye can take advantage of some of their switch-ins like Gastrodon and Reuniclus. Fire-types such as Entei and Chandelure can outspeed and revenge kill Decidueye, so answers to these threats like Gastrodon and Milotic make excellent partners. Incineroar counters Decidueye, so partners that can threaten it are near essential, such as Heracross and Starmie. Pokemon like Metagross and Flygon appreciate Decidueye's ability to threaten bulky Water-types; in return, Metagross checks Flying-types such as Togekiss and Crobat, while Flygon can pressure checks like Incineroar and Registeel.

Incineroar.overview: Incineroar's typing, decent mixed bulk, and Intimidate make it a resilient pivot that checks threats such as Chandelure, Celebi, Reuniclus, and Dhelmise. It also has some very useful utility moves; Knock Off is great for removing Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots from targets such as Gastrodon, Noivern, and Togekiss, while Toxic can catch and wear down threats such as Gastrodon, Diancie, and opposing Incineroar. However, Incineroar has no recovery to speak of. This is somewhat mitigated by Heavy-Duty Boots removing entry hazard damage from the equation, but it does make Incineroar very vulnerable to Knock Off and Toxic. Incineroar's typing is overall quite good, but leaves it with annoying weaknesses to Water, Ground, and Fighting, which are exploited by threats such as Sharpedo, Flygon, Lucario, and Heracross.
Incineroar.comments:
Other Options

A set utilizing Bulk Up, Power Trip, Flame Charge, and Drain Punch with a Weakness Policy can be used on dual screens hyper offense as a devastating sweeper. Various weakness Berries can be utilized to let Incineroar lure in specific threats; Chople Berry can be used for Lucario, while Shuca Berry can give Incineroar a buffer against Metagross. Losing Heavy-Duty Boots is hugely detrimental, however, and puts a ton of pressure on your team's entry hazard control.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Bulky Water-types, such as Milotic, Gastrodon, and Suicune, switch into Incineroar's Overheat and threaten it with STAB moves or Toxic. Suicune is also capable of setting up on Incineroar, but it must be careful not to switch directly into Knock Off. Offensive Water-types, such as Sharpedo, Starmie, and Kingdra, are also threatening, although their frailty means they must be very cautious about switching in.

Rock-types: Stakataka and Diancie take Incineroar's STAB moves quite well and use it to set up Stealth Rock or fire off an attack. Neither really wants to take Knock Off or Toxic, however. Barbaracle is also capable of forcing Incineroar out and setting up.

Fighting-types and Fighting-type coverage: Heracross, Bewear, Pangoro, and Lucario all outrun and force out Incineroar with the threat of their STAB moves, although none of them can switch in reliably. Additionally, Pokemon that Incineroar can usually pivot into, such as Reuniclus and Doublade, can viably run Fighting-type coverage and deal great damage.

Knock Off: Incineroar is heavily reliant on Heavy-Duty Boots to stay healthy and check what it needs to throughout a match, so Knock Off from threats such as Golisopod, Reuniclus, Salazzle, and opposing Incineroar is hugely detrimental to it.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Overheat is preferred over Flare Blitz due to it hitting targets such as Steelix, Bewear, Metagross, and Doublade harder while preserving Incineroar's HP. Toxic can catch threats such as Gastrodon, Diancie, and Milotic, although Swords Dance can improve Incineroar's matchup against Calm Mind Reuniclus and Strength Sap Polteageist. Incineroar is quite effective at spreading Toxic, as most Steel- and Poison-types do not want to switch into Overheat or Knock Off. U-turn is preferred for pivoting because Clear Body and Magic Bounce users cannot block it and because most Rocky Helmet users aren't eager to switch into Incineroar. Parting Shot weakens foes instead, giving a bit more safety to frail attackers, such as Gardevoir, Heliolisk, and Starmie, and setup sweepers, such as Cloyster, Mimikyu, and Barbaracle. A Sassy nature is used because Incineroar is pretty slow already and it doesn't want to weaken either of its main attacks, while a specially defensive spread improves Incineroar's matchup against threats such as Chandelure, Salazzle, and Roserade. 20 Attack EVs ensure that Knock Off OHKOes Chandelure.

Incineroar properly switching into Chandelure and being a great buffer against most Fire-types is appreciated by many Grass-types. These include Celebi, Roserade, Dhelmise, and Vileplume, all of which can check Ground- and Water-types such as Flygon, Gastrodon, Sharpedo, and Suicune. The latter three also provide a resistance to Fighting, which can prove very useful against threats such as Cobalion. Incineroar really wants to keep its Heavy-Duty Boots; Galarian Weezing and Rocky Helmet Cobalion can work as Knock Off absorbers. Psychic-type teammates, such as Reuniclus and Gardevoir, appreciate Incineroar pivoting into dangerous Ghost-types such as Chandelure and Mimikyu. Incineroar's ability to weaken foes with Parting Shot is appreciated by frailer offensive teammates, such as Xurkitree, Gardevoir, and Golurk, and gives setup opportunities to sweepers such as Cloyster, Barbaracle, Lucario, and Raikou.

sets.name: Sticky Web
sets.description:
Ribombee's access to Sticky Web, high Speed tier, and support movepool allow it to carve a niche as a reliable Sticky Web setter. U-turn lets Ribombee pivot its teammates into favorable matchups. Stun Spore paralyzes Crobat, allowing Ribombee's teammates to easily revenge kill it and keep Sticky Web up by denying Defog. Focus Sash lets Ribombee survive any one hit from foes like Choice Scarf Heracross, Choice Scarf Flygon, and Talonflame.

Pokemon such as Slurpuff, Polteageist, and Cloyster can find setup opportunities against common revenge killers such as Raikou and Choice Scarf Flygon. Lucario, Xurkitree, and Mimikyu are effective Sticky Web users, as they are harder to revenge kill with Sticky Web up. Sticky Web teams appreciate having fast Pokemon like Raikou and Cobalion, which are not completely reliant on Sticky Web to be effective. With Sticky Web up, they outspeed Choice Scarf users like Gardevoir and Xurkitree.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Salazzle's high Speed, powerful STAB combination, and access to Nasty Plot give it immense wallbreaking potential. Toxic and Corrosion allow Salazzle to pressure most of its checks, including Gastrodon, Milotic, and Dragalge. Knock Off can be used over Nasty Plot to further punish Salazzle's switch-ins by removing items such as Leftovers, Heavy-Duty Boots, and Assault Vest.

Salazzle appreciates Fighting-type wallbreakers that help it with specially defensive walls such as Umbreon and Snorlax, with Heracross, Bewear, and Lucario being good options. Salazzle has bad defensive stats, so it appreciates having pivots like Milotic, Raikou, and Noivern to bring it in unharmed. Salazzle relies on entry hazard support from Klefki, Roserade, or Golisopod so it can OHKO foes with its powerful STAB attacks. Grass-types such as Dhelmise, Celebi, and Decidueye help Salazzle against Water- and Rock-type checks such as Gastrodon and Diancie. Electric-types such as Toxtricity and Xurkitree are also good teammates because they can pressure Water-type Pokemon, get Salazzle onto the field safely with Volt Switch, and further wear down special sponges such as Porygon2 and Umbreon.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Bewear is an incredibly strong wallbreaker that uses Fluffy and its typing to take advantage of staples like Golisopod, Steelix, and Registeel. However, its low Speed and Special Defense leaves it easy pickings for common faster special attackers such as Noivern, Nidoqueen, and Xurkitree. Drain Punch mitigates damage from tanking physical attacks and recoil from using Double-Edge. At +2 Attack, Close Combat gets OHKOs that Drain Punch misses out on such as against Steelix and Diancie after Stealth Rock. Darkest Lariat covers Ghost-types like Chandelure, Mimikyu, and Dhelmise while also providing a hard-hitting move without recoil for Psychic-types like Reuniclus and Celebi. Chople Berry prevents faster threats such as Heracross and Lucario from easily revenge killing Bewear, while Silk Scarf boosts Double-Edge for an almost guaranteed OHKO on Reuniclus and Galarian Weezing after Stealth Rock. Jolly is the preferred nature to outspeed Pangoro and Choice Band Metagross. Silk Scarf variants can run an Adamant nature to OHKO Reuniclus after Swords Dance while ensuring the OHKO on Galarian Weezing after Stealth Rock.

VoltTurn support is invaluable for Bewear, as it often struggles to safely switch in. Raikou, Noivern, and Crobat are notable examples, as they can provide a free switch against Pokemon that Bewear takes advantage of such as Steelix and Registeel. Stealth Rock support is crucial for important KOs like against Galarian Weezing with +2 Silk Scarf-boosted Double-Edge. Diancie can check Fire-types such as Entei and Chandelure, while Nidoqueen can check other revenge killers like Xurkitree and Raikou. Steel-types such as Metagross, Registeel, and Klefki also set up hazards and deal with major nuisances for Bewear like Togekiss, Noivern, Crobat, and Gardevoir. Klefki is also notable for providing Thunder Wave to slow down faster threats like Noivern. Other Spikers such as Roserade and Golisopod help wear down walls while the latter provides additional support in Knock Off. Roserade also checks Electric-types trying to revenge kill Bewear such as Raikou and Xurkitree. Pokemon such as Flygon, Noivern, and Sharpedo appreciate Bewear denting Fairy-types like Togekiss and Galarian Weezing. Bewear is an excellent Knock Off absorber and can come in on Knock Off users trying to remove valuable items from Pokemon like Togekiss, Noivern, and Reuniclus.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Without wasting a turn, Choice Band Bewear utilizes its Fluffy ability and typing to switch into common Pokemon such as Golisopod and immediately fire off incredibly strong attacks. However, as a wallbreaker, it is greatly hindered by its prediction-reliant nature, and with its average Speed, faster special attackers such as Noivern, Togekiss, and Toxtricity can effortlessly revenge kill it. The recovery from Drain Punch prevents Bewear from quickly getting worn down from tanking physical attacks and using Double-Edge. Darkest Lariat nails Ghost-types such as Chandelure, Mimikyu, and Jellicent. A Jolly nature is used to outspeed Pangoro.

VoltTurn support is invaluable for Bewear, as it often struggles to safely switch in. Raikou, Noivern, and Xurkitree are notable examples, as they can provide a free switch against Pokemon that Bewear takes advantage of such as Assault Vest Reuniclus, Steelix, and Registeel. Steel-types such as Metagross, Registeel, and Klefki deal with a major nuisance for Bewear in Flying-types like Togekiss, Noivern, and Crobat. Klefki is also notable for providing Spikes support and Thunder Wave to slow down faster threats like Noivern. Spikes support is appreciated to punish attempts to pivot around Bewear's Choice-locked attacks. Spikers such as Roserade and Golisopod also provide great additional support. Golisopod can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from shared switch-ins such as Crobat and Togekiss. Roserade, on the other hand, checks Electric-types trying to revenge kill Bewear such as Raikou and Xurkitree. Pokemon such as Flygon, Noivern, and Sharpedo appreciate Bewear denting Fairy-types like Togekiss and Galarian Weezing.

sets.name: Rapid Spin
sets.description:
In a tier filled to the brim with viable Grass-types, Tsareena's access to Rapid Spin, Knock Off, good coverage, and a decent Speed tier are just enough to carve itself a niche. In particular, its higher Speed stat is what differentiates it from Dhelmise and lets it outspeed the whole unboosted metagame after a Rapid Spin. Tsareena's vulnerability to Toxic and difficulty to fit Synthesis make it unable to naturally switch into Electric- and Water-types like Raikou, Xurkitree, and Gastrodon unlike other Grass-types such as Roserade, Vileplume, and Celebi. Knock Off removes crucial items like Heavy-Duty Boots from switch-ins such as Incineroar while not giving away any free switches to Chandelure and Metagross. Triple Axel catches Flying- and Grass-types such as Togekiss, Noivern, and Vileplume on the switch. High Jump Kick, U-turn, and Synthesis are all great options, but without either Knock Off or Triple Axel, Tsareena is left completely vulnerable to common threats like Metagross and Togekiss. With Heavy-Duty Boots, Tsareena can repeatedly switch into entry hazards to remove them with Rapid Spin. Queenly Majesty protects Tsareena from priority moves like Golisopod's First Impression, which lets it win the matchup and keep entry hazards off the field.

On its own, Tsareena isn't a very reliable switch-in to Electric- and Water-types like Raikou and Milotic, but more reliable checks such as Gastrodon and Guzzlord can pick up the slack. While Flying-types such as Togekiss, Crobat, and Tornadus need to watch out for Triple Axel, they all outspeed and threaten Tsareena with their STAB moves. Metagross, Raikou, and Diancie can check said Flying-types for Tsareena. Poison-types such as Roserade, Toxicroak, and Galarian Weezing can either threaten or wall Tsareena. Roserade is especially a nuisance, as it's a Spikes setter that Tsareena loses to. Pokemon such as Crobat can check Roserade while Gastrodon helps with the latter two. Pokemon such as Tornadus, Suicune, and Heracross are ravaged by entry hazards and greatly appreciate Tsareena spinning them away.

Golisopod.overview: First Impression Golisopod is a reliable revenge killer for many common threats such as Dragon Dance Flygon, Celebi, and Xurkitree. Additionally, its combination of the crippling Knock Off and Spikes makes it a great offensive supporter able to punish nearly every switch-in and play around of some of its typical checks. Golisopod's typing and physical bulk allow it to check some strong threats such as Metagross, physical Sharpedo, and Flygon as well. However, after First Impression is used, Golisopod is easy to revenge kill due to its low Speed stat and mediocre special bulk. Golisopod also struggles against many common bulky Pokemon such as Milotic, Gastrodon, and Vileplume, particularly the Water-types. Although its Emergency Exit might be helpful in some situations, getting forced to switch out is disadvantageous in most cases.
Golisopod.comments:
Other Options

Close Combat allows Golisopod to 2HKO Registeel, OHKO Lucario, and hit Water-types for decent damage.

Checks and Counters

Bulky Water-types: Bulky Water-types such as Seismitoad, Milotic, and Gastrodon take very little from Golisopod's moves and threaten it with a Scald burn or Toxic poison. However, they do not want to lose their items to Golisopod's Knock Off.

Various Bulky Pokemon: Various bulky Pokemon such as Vileplume, Galarian Weezing, and Bewear can easily switch into Golisopod's STAB moves and quickly KO it or activate Emergency Exit. Toxicroak deserves a special mention despite not being bulky, as it easily takes advantage of Golisopod due to its typing and ability. However, none of these Pokemon like having their items removed by Knock Off. Pokemon such as Galarian Weezing and Bewear are easy to wear down due to their lack of reliable recovery.

Flying-types: Flying-types such as Noivern, Togekiss, and Crobat easily revenge kill Golisopod and switch into its First Impression. However, they should watch out for Knock Off because they rely a ton on their Heavy-Duty Boots to prevent Stealth Rock damage.

Electric-types: Once they get a safe switch in, Electric-types such as Raikou, Heliolisk, and Xurkitree OHKO Golisopod or activate Emergency Exit.

Strong Attackers: Although Golisopod has respectable bulk, strong wallbreakers such as Chandelure, Heracross, and Golurk easily defeat it or force it out by activating its ability. Indeedee deserves special attention, because its Psychic Terrain prevents Golisopod from using First Impression against grounded targets.

sets.name: Revenge Killer
sets.description:
Leech Life gives Golisopod the option to heal itself and, more importantly, check Calm Mind Reuniclus and hit Grass-, Psychic-, and Dark-types such as Celebi and Umbreon super effectively after First Impression is used. Aqua Jet makes Golisopod more difficult to revenge kill and able to revenge kill Pokemon such as Chandelure, Salazzle, and Aerodactyl. However, without a strong and reliable STAB move in Liquidation, Golisopod becomes a bit too weak against bulky Pokemon such as Registeel, Klefki, and Escavalier. Knock Off punishes Golisopod's typical switch-ins such as Noivern, Togekiss, and Milotic. In addition, removing Heavy-Duty Boots from grounded switch-ins such as Gastrodon enables Golisopod to wear them down with Spikes. Heavy-Duty Boots gives Golisopod more switch-in opportunities by negating its severe entry hazard weakness. The listed Speed EVs allow Golisopod to outspeed Pokemon with uninvested base 50 Speed such as Diancie, Registeel, and Vileplume. The remaining EVs are dumped into HP, allowing Golisopod to better switch into Metagross's and Flygon's attacks.

Golisopod works well on balance and bulky offensive teams that need a reliable revenge killer for common threats such as Xurkitree, Dragon Dance Flygon, and Nasty Plot Celebi and appreciate a reliable Spikes setter. Powerful wallbreakers such as Metagross, Toxtricity, and Gardevoir appreciate Golisopod's Spikes support. In return, they handle troublesome bulky Pokemon such as Vileplume, Galarian Weezing, and Gastrodon. Strong late-game cleaners like Mimikyu, Sharpedo, and Xurkitree are also good examples of Pokemon that appreciate Spikes support. Grass- and Electric-types such as Vileplume, Celebi, and Xurkitree check bulky Water-types that Golisopod struggles with such as Milotic, Gastrodon, and Suicune. Bulky Rock- and Steel-types such as Diancie, Stakataka, and Metagross, on the other hand, check strong Flying-types such as Togekiss, Noivern, and Crobat. These Pokemon also form a great hazard stacking core with Golisopod, as they are reliable Stealth Rock setters. Beyond that, they appreciate Golisopod's ability to remove Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off. Specially defensive Pokemon such as Steelix, Assault Vest Reuniclus, and Snorlax are great to reliably check the tier's strong Electric-types.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Mimikyu is a sweeper with a great STAB combination but middling power. Disguise has a number of uses, including revenge killing faster sweepers, granting Mimikyu a free turn to set up, and ensuring that Mimikyu itself is not revenge killed. Notably, Disguise does not protect Mimikyu against status moves or the secondary effects of moves like Scald. Shadow Sneak gives Mimikyu a way to pick off weakened faster Pokemon like Noivern and Crobat. Shadow Claw hits Pokemon that resist Play Rough like Metagross, Crobat, Volcanion, Alolan Marowak, and Galarian Weezing. Drain Punch misses out on the aforementioned targets but hits Steel-types like Steelix, Registeel, and Stakataka much harder than Shadow Claw. Finally, Wood Hammer can be used to hit the likes of Suicune, Milotic, and Rhyperior harder than any of Mimikyu's other moves.

Mimikyu is best suited to hyper offense or bulky offense teams that appreciate the safety net Disguise provides against faster threats. The most significant Mimikyu check in the tier is Zarude, which outspeeds Mimikyu and OHKOes it with Power Whip once Disguise is broken, and can safely U-turn if Disguise is still intact. Zarude can be checked by Crobat, Klefki, and Talonflame. Rhyperior can lure in Zarude and KO it with Megahorn, making it another good partner. Mimikyu must be sure to weaken Cobalion before attempting to sweep; it can be checked by Golisopod and Talonflame, while Sharpedo and Cloyster can wear down Cobalion due to it repeatedly switching into them. Steelix is able to halt a Mimikyu sweep if it's healthy enough, so Pokemon able to wear it down like Xurkitree and Necrozma also make for good partners. The majority of Mimikyu's answers are vulnerable to Spikes, which Golisopod, Roserade, and Klefki can provide.

Dhelmise.overview: Dhelmise is one of the few viable spinners and supports entry hazard-stacking builds. Thanks to its bulk and typing, it can switch into Stealth Rock setters such as Bronzong, Diancie, and Steelix and force them out. In addition, it boasts a high base Attack and two powerful STAB moves, allowing it to deal good damage to any given team. Dhelmise can switch into and force out Electric-types, but it can lose momentum against them due to Volt Switch. Despite its defensive utility, Dhelmise struggles long-term due to its vulnerability to status and Synthesis's low PP. Dark-types, as well as Ghost-types like Mimikyu, Golurk, and Polteageist, outspeed and threaten it. Dhelmise also faces competition from Celebi and Roserade as a Grass-type wallbreaker.
Dhelmise.comments:
Other Options

Knock Off is a great option on entry hazard-stacking teams to cripple foes, but it forces Dhelmise to drop Poltergeist, which allows Pokemon like Lucario and Klefki to handle it better. Swords Dance provides extra wallbreaking power, which is useful against foes like itemless Calm Mind Reuniclus. A set with Anchor Shot, Rest, and Rapid Spin can be used to trap and eliminate Steel-type Stealth Rock setters such as Registeel and Stakataka. However, it is too passive outside of this niche and allows setup sweepers like Swords Dance Lucario and Nasty Plot Togekiss to take advantage of Dhelmise. Beyond that set, Anchor Shot hits Togekiss and Galarian Weezing and gains the boost from Steelworker.

Checks and Counters

Flying-types: Although Dhelmise can 2HKO Togekiss, Crobat, and Noivern, they force it out thanks to their high Speed and super effective attacks.

Dark-types: Umbreon and Incineroar, in particular, give Dhelmise the most trouble, as the former can OHKO it with Foul Play and the latter resists both of its STAB moves. Other Dark-types such as Pangoro and Sharpedo can give it major issues with their Dark-type moves and wallbreaking presence.

Other Faster Threats: Fire-types like Entei and Chandelure as well as Pokemon such as Heracross and Sharpedo easily force Dhelmise out. This makes it difficult to maintain momentum after KOing a Pokemon.

Status and Chip Damage: When badly poisoned by Gastrodon, Diancie, or Raikou, Dhelmise struggles to check Electric-types effectively. Residual damage from Volt Switch and U-turn further compounds this issue, and Synthesis only has 8 PP, which reduces Dhelmise's longevity.

Ghost-types: Although Ghost-types like Polteageist, Golurk, and Chandelure cannot switch into Poltergeist, they can switch in on a predicted Rapid Spin and force Dhelmise out.

sets.name: Offensive Utility
sets.description:
Poltergeist scares most of the tier, even key Flying-types such as Crobat, Noivern, and Togekiss, which outspeed Dhelmise and threaten it with super effective attacks while also having recovery. It also prevents many Pokemon, such as Heracross, Golurk, and Chandelure, from directly switching in. Power Whip is mainly used to hit Stealth Rock setters, Dark-types, and Normal-types. Synthesis improves Dhelmise's longevity and lets it check Xurkitree, Raikou, and Toxtricity, but it has low PP, which means Dhelmise should be wary of chip damage from attacks like Volt Switch. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Dhelmise to use Rapid Spin more effectively. 192 HP EVs allow Dhelmise to avoid the 2HKO from Choice Specs Toxtricity's Overdrive, while 100 Speed EVs allow it to outspeed Sassy Incineroar, as well as Golurk and Stealth Rock Metagross after Rapid Spin.

Dark-types like Umbreon and Incineroar and Normal-types like Snorlax and Porygon2 are problematic for Dhelmise, as they make Poltergeist harder to spam. Dhelmise can break through some of these Pokemon with Power Whip, as it has a good chance to 2HKO Umbreon and Porygon2 after Stealth Rock, but they can threaten it with Foul Play. Fighting-types like Bewear and Heracross can help take down these threats more reliably. Dhelmise is relatively slow, which allows many threats to revenge kill it. Bulkier threats such as Golisopod and Nidoqueen can take one of its attacks and do big damage in return. Pokemon like Gastrodon and Umbreon therefore pair well with Dhelmise, as they blanket check a lot of the tier. In return, it can apply offensive pressure and clear entry hazards for them. Dhelmise also struggles with status and is often crippled by threats it switches into, like Steelix and Bronzong, which reduces its ability to check Raikou, Xurkitree, and Toxtricity. Pairing Dhelmise with Heal Bell is a great way to prevent this issue; most Heal Bell users also provide Wish support, reducing Dhelmise's reliance on Synthesis.

Xurkitree.overview: Of RU's three best Electric-types, Xurkitree, Raikou, and Toxtricity, Xurkitree is commonly considered the most restrictive and consistently dangerous for one simple reason: Grass-type coverage. Its Heavy-Duty Boots set singlehandedly makes Gastrodon, a strong Raikou answer, insufficient for covering the metagame's Electric-types, and other Ground-types like Steelix and Flygon shaky at best. With Ground-types so hesitant to face Xurkitree, it's free to use Volt Switch on switch-ins like Grass-types and special walls, which are rife with weaknesses for teammates to exploit. It's at its strongest against bulkier cores, which often use slower, exploitable Pokemon like Togekiss and Water-types and which struggle to pressure it with passive damage thanks to its Heavy-Duty Boots. While its Speed and bulk aren't great against offensive teams, it can usually find at least one opportunity to threaten them as well, either by forcing a switch or taking a hit. Should its team call for it, it can use Choice Scarf for greater use against offense and potentially cleaning up with Beast Boost at the expense of threatening defensive cores. What generally holds Xurkitree back is its aforementioned bulk and Speed; it can't switch into many direct attacks, and it often has very little breathing room against offense, areas where Raikou beats it out. Its Choice Scarf set suffers from prediction reliance against Ground-types and failing to outspeed other Choice Scarf users like Heracross and Flygon, limiting its ability to revenge kill and clean up. If you're looking for raw attacking power, you might prefer Toxtricity, whose Boomburst is easier to spam and much stronger than any of Xurkitree's individual attacks.
Xurkitree.comments:
Other Options

Endure + Salac Berry has merit on Sticky Web teams, giving Xurkitree the simultaneous benefits of heightened Speed and attack freedom while blocking First Impression and outpacing Choice Scarf users not named Flygon. If you build around Indeedee-M, its Psychic Surge lets Xurkitree run Nature Power to OHKO Roserade, Vileplume, and Nidoqueen.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Roserade, Celebi, Vileplume, and Dhelmise are popular alongside Ground-types to minimize the damage Xurkitree can do, given their Electric resistance and neutrality-at-worst to its coverage. They're vulnerable to Volt Switch, though, so Xurkitree's team will often stay at an advantage, and Vileplume's and Dhelmise's lower Speed means Xurkitree doesn't even need to predict them.

Special Walls: Bulky Pokemon like Diancie, Registeel, Assault Vest Reuniclus, Porygon2, and Umbreon stand up well to Xurkitree's unboosted attacks but are total Volt Switch fodder. They need Heavy-Duty Boots Xurkitree statused or itemless to win a battle of attrition.

Ground-types: Steelix's Grass neutrality makes it the best Ground-type Xurkitree switch-in, though it quickly loses to repeated Grass Knot or Energy Ball. Flygon can take Dazzling Gleam once with the right EVs. Other Ground-types such as Gastrodon and Golurk usually switch out when Xurkitree appears in fear of Grass-type moves but can punish overeager uses of Volt Switch. Any Ground-type is a serious problem for Choice Scarf Xurkitree, creating a cost for locking into Electric-type moves.

Electric-types: With resistance to Electric and neutrality to Grass and Fairy, other Electric-types like Raikou, Toxtricity, and Xurkitree itself make for decent early-game switch-ins to Xurkitree. Only Toxtricity threatens much damage back, however, and none of them are eager to keep losing HP.

Faster Pokemon and Priority: Offensive teams featuring a lot of fast Pokemon give Heavy-Duty Boots Xurkitree few easy entry points and seldom lose more than one Pokemon to it. Faster Choice Scarf users like Flygon and Heracross can revenge kill weakened Choice Scarf Xurkitree. The same goes for strong priority from the likes of Golisopod and Lucario.

Alolan Marowak: Lighting Rod Alolan Marowak is unique in that it's immune to Electric and resistant to both Grass and Fairy, making it a major early-game obstacle to Xurkitree, but it's uncommon, very flawed, and fairly easy to wear down.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description:
Heavy-Duty Boots Xurkitree uses its entry hazard immunity and great coverage to give bulky cores a hard time. Thunderbolt and Volt Switch are staple moves for an Electric-type pivot. A Grass-type move threatens Ground-types; Grass Knot also does the most damage to Steelix, Raikou, and other Xurkitree, while Energy Ball properly hurts the lightweight Diancie and always OHKOes Gastrodon. Dazzling Gleam covers Flygon and is Xurkitree's strongest option against certain Grass-types like Dhelmise and Celebi.

Pivot Xurkitree is pretty good at its job by default, so it usually gets put on a proactive team later in the building process to support others and pressure Togekiss. Steel-, Flying-, and Fire-types such as Metagross, Noivern, and Salazzle like having Xurkitree use Volt Switch as Grass-types like Roserade and Celebi switch in, and Fighting- and Ground-types like Heracross and Flygon can take advantage of special walls such as Porygon2 and Registeel. Xurkitree is pretty slow and unwieldy against offense, so it should have at least a couple of fast teammates, some conventional examples including Noivern, Starmie, and Choice Scarf Flygon.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Xurkitree's increased Speed makes it more useful against offense and able to leverage Beast Boost late-game. Thunderbolt and Volt Switch are must-haves for most Electric-types, Energy Ball consistently covers Ground-types, and Dazzling Gleam handles Dragon-types while boasting decent neutral coverage for cleaning up.

Choice Scarf Xurkitree has a lot of opportunity cost compared to Heavy-Duty Boots Xurkitree, so it's only well merited when its team needs an Electric-type and a revenge killer in one. Given its focus on revenge killing and cleaning up, its teammates should include a wallbreaker or two like Flame Orb Heracross and Choice Band Metagross, which punish special walls and Grass-types. Water- and Grass-types like Milotic, Gastrodon, and Celebi can handle Ground-types when Xurkitree loses momentum to them. Roserade offensively checks them and sets Spikes, but it isn't a good Earthquake switch-in. Choice Scarf Xurkitree is still slower than other Choice Scarf users, so a priority user such as Golisopod or Bullet Punch Metagross will often be necessary on offensive teams using it.

Stakataka.overview: Stakataka is one of the better defensive Pokemon in the RU metagame due to its incredible bulk, defensive typing, and utility move options. It functions primarily as a Stealth Rock user for bulky offensive and balanced teams. Stakataka's main advantage over its Stealth Rock-setting competition in Metagross, Registeel, and Bronzong is its typing. Its combination of Fire neutrality and Flying, Fairy, and Psychic resistances means it checks many common threats utilizing Fire-type coverage like Togekiss and Noivern in addition to Chandelure. Unfortunately, since Stakataka's the slowest Pokemon in the tier, it's usually getting hit first and worn down easily, and it is forced to make predictions even when other defensive Pokemon are switching in. Its 4x Ground and Fighting weaknesses mean it finds itself offensively pressured a lot.
Stakataka.comments:
Other Options

Choice Band can be used to punch holes in opposing teams and catch the opponent off guard. However, due to Stakataka's slow Speed and Choice lock, it can easily be set up on. Shuca Berry or Chople Berry on the defensive set allows Stakataka to tank an attack from threats like Flygon and Metagross or Heracross and Mimikyu. Unfortunately, Stakataka sorely misses passive recovery, and taking a super effective attack will likely leave it with little HP remaining anyway. An offensive Trick Room set can work as a cleaner, although there are better sweepers that don't have to rely on Trick Room.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types and Fighting-type Coverage: Due to Stakataka's 4x weakness to Fighting, threats like Heracross, Pangoro, and Lucario are just a few Pokemon that send it running. None of them want to switch into it, however. Body Press Registeel and Aura Sphere Raikou are just a couple of threats with coverage to also exploit this weakness.

Ground-types and Ground-type Coverage: Pokemon like Golurk, Nidoqueen, and Gastrodon have little to fear from Stakataka and force it out. Metagross, Aerodactyl, and even opposing Stakataka are just a few Pokemon that carry Earthquake as a coverage move and can severely hurt Stakataka.

Bulky Water-types: Milotic, Suicune, and Gastrodon can come in safely on Stakataka and heal any damage, although they have to be wary of switching into Toxic.

sets.name: Defensive Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Body Press hits Steel-types the hardest and takes advantage of Defense boosts from Beast Boost. Toxic cripples switch-ins to Stakataka like Gastrodon and Milotic. Stone Edge, however, nails Chandelure, Salazzle, and Golisopod. Leftovers gives Stakataka some staying power over the course of a match, especially against Air Slash flinches from Togekiss. 0 Speed IVs and a Sassy nature make Gyro Ball as strong as possible.

Stakataka's typing gives it some more weaknesses than other Steel-types; its Water weakness makes it worse against threats like Sharpedo and Suicune, while its gnarly quadruple weaknesses to Ground and Fighting ruin its ability to check threats like Steelix, Metagross, Raikou, and Celebi. Teams wielding Stakataka must cover its glaring weaknesses with the rest of their defensive core. Water- and Grass-types such as Milotic, Suicune, Dhelmise, and Celebi can take on threatening Water-types for Stakataka. Certain Grass-types can also take on threatening Ground-types such as Flygon and Golurk, as can Bug-types like Heracross and Golisopod. Options like Togekiss and Crobat are solid checks to Fighting-types like Heracross and Pangoro. Grass-type teammates like Roserade appreciate Stakataka being a decent switch-in to Fire-types and stonewalling most of the tier's Flying-types. Stakataka's sturdy resistance to Toxtricity's Boomburst and ability to deal with Xurkitree to an extent can give Ground-types like Gastrodon some breathing room. Stakataka fails to keep Stealth Rock up against Defog Flygon and Rapid Spin Starmie. Pokemon like Choice Scarf Gardevoir can threaten Flygon, and Electric-types such as Raikou and Xurkitree can force Starmie out consistently.

Toxtricity.overview: Choice Specs Toxtricity is one of RU's strongest sources of immediate damage thanks to its Punk Rock-boosted Boomburst, which has very few consistent switch-ins. Pokemon with the typing or special bulk to take Boomburst, like Stakataka and Porygon2, are vulnerable to Toxtricity's coverage or lose momentum to Volt Switch. Though slow, Toxtricity poses a massive early-game threat to offensive teams, as staples like Noivern cannot immediately OHKO it and fear getting OHKOed in return. Its resistances let it even switch into and punish Crobat, Roserade, and Raikou once or twice, especially if they go for utility moves. Once Toxtricity has taken some damage, however, it becomes much less of a threat, as its low Speed and bulk will make it easy for many Pokemon to pick off. Its vulnerability to Stealth Rock and Spikes worsens this issue, especially in a metagame full of pivots using Heavy-Duty Boots, which incentivizes conventional offensive teams to forgo entry hazard removal. It faces competition from RU's more reliable Electric-types, such as Xurkitree, Heliolisk, and Raikou; the former can use Choice Scarf to similarly threaten offense or Heavy-Duty Boots to wallbreak like Toxtricity without fearing entry hazards, while the latter two's naturally high Speed stats lets them remain a threat to offense all game long. The other Electric-types are always faster than offensive Togekiss, which can overcome weakened Toxtricity with Air Slash flinches.
Toxtricity.comments:
Other Options

A Shift Gear set using Boomburst, Overdrive, Drain Punch, and Life Orb with maximum Special Attack and Speed investment and a Hasty nature can be a nasty surprise sweeper that beats and sets up on Porygon2. With so many other sweepers and Choice Scarf users available, including Sharpedo, Cloyster, Mimikyu, Xurkitree, and Heracross, dedicating Toxtricity to the role is usually unnecessary and a waste of its power.

Checks and Counters

Entry Hazards and Offensive Pressure: Offensive teams often won't have a solid switch-in to Toxtricity beyond a one-time check like Steelix; they bank on trading damage with it or wearing it down with Stealth Rock and Spikes until it's in KO range of faster Pokemon. Toxtricity's unremarkable bulk means this won't take long. Most aggressive teams will also give Toxtricity very few opportunities to directly switch in.

Ghost-types: The presence of a Ghost-type forces Toxtricity to think twice about spamming Boomburst, limiting how much damage it can get out of its attack opportunities. Golurk and Lightning Rod Alolan Marowak are even immune to Electric, meaning Toxtricity has to risk using the generally mediocre Snarl or Sludge Bomb. Colbur Berry Dhelmise can take a hit from Toxtricity pretty well. Ghost-types generally work well with Ground-types by maximizing the number of predictions Toxtricity has to make.

Specially Bulky Pokemon: Snorlax and Registeel can stand up to Toxtricity's attacks for a while, though they lose momentum to Volt Switch and are easily pressured. Diancie and Stakataka can switch into Boomburst but hate Electric-type attacks. Steelix and Assault Vest Reuniclus can switch into Boomburst once and threaten to KO in return. Porygon2 takes Toxtricity's attacks comfortably due to Trace copying Punk Rock, however, Porygon2 is vulnerable to Volt Switch, very flawed, and rare.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Punk Rock Toxtricity's Boomburst has obscene power and coverage, OHKOing or 2HKOing most Pokemon and even 3HKOing Steelix. Overdrive is a consistent Electric-type attack that punishes Boomburst switch-ins like Stakataka and Diancie. Volt Switch lets Toxtricity bring a threatening teammate in against relatively consistent checks like Porygon2 and Registeel. Snarl catches the occasional Golurk along with OHKOing Alolan Marowak. Sludge Bomb is an alternative that can poison bulky switch-ins, 2HKOes Alolan Marowak, and OHKOes Trace Gardevoir. Toxtricity's Speed tier isn't crowded, so it can get away with a Modest nature. Running a Timid nature is advantageous against Tyrantrum, Modest Nidoqueen, and other Toxtricity, though it makes Pokemon harder to OHKO with Boomburst.

Proactive teams using offensive pivots like Noivern and Crobat are best at giving Toxtricity chances to freely attack and compensating for its poor Speed. Flygon and Incineroar are U-turn users that pivot on switch-ins like Togekiss and Galarian Weezing, which healthy Toxtricity is then free to exploit. They form a VoltTurn core with Toxtricity as well, giving defensive teams a miserable time. Other Fighting-types like Heracross punish bulky Normal- and Steel-types for switching into Boomburst. Toxtricity is a very self-sufficient attacker once it's made it into the battle, so its team doesn't need to give it much specific support; just have a plan for when common threats switch in to revenge kill it.

Polteageist.overview: Polteageist is an excellent Shell Smash sweeper due to its useful offensive typing and good stats, and the combination of Cursed Body and Strength Sap allows it to stall out, disable, and break through the majority of its checks such as Obstagoon and Snorlax. Polteageist is a great pick on hyper offense, where it can be supported properly and form wallbreaking cores with Pokemon like Lucario. However, Polteageist's shallow offensive movepool means it must pick whether it gets walled by either Dark-types or Normal-types, and it cannot hope to outlast Pokemon like Umbreon. It also relies on fishing for Cursed Body to get past its checks, and status effects can limit its longevity to the point where it isn't feasible to do so.
Polteageist.comments:
Other Options

Polteageist can run Stored Power + Giga Drain to hit both Dark- and Normal-types on the same set, although it doesn't really have the space for it. Weak Armor and Focus Sash might appear enticing, but losing out on Cursed Body and White Herb makes it less effective at outlasting its checks.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Due to its lack of coverage, Dark-types are the biggest roadblocks preventing a Polteageist sweep. Umbreon completely blanks Polteageist and can use the opportunity to use Wish or Heal Bell. Similarly, Stored Power variants are unable to touch Obstagoon. Incineroar beats Polteageist unless severely weakened, although Toxic variants may lose with Misty Terrain support. A healthy Pangoro can break through Polteageist's Strength Sap, although Giga Drain can dent it.

Status: Toxic puts Polteageist on a timer, preventing it from spamming Strength Sap and fishing for Cursed Body, while paralysis leaves it vulnerable to faster revenge killers.

Normal-types: Without Stored Power, Polteageist can be threatened by Normal-types such as Snorlax and Porygon2, which can stall it out through Rest or Toxic. Choice Band Bewear and Choice Specs Indeedee can also check Polteageist if healthy. However, all of them can lose if sufficiently weakened.

Priority: Certain types of priority can cut a Polteageist sweep short, such as Shadow Sneak from Doublade, Mimikyu, and Decidueye, Thunder Wave from Klefki, and, if sufficiently weakened, First Impression from Golisopod and Flygon.

sets.name: Shell Smash
sets.description:
Polteageist stalls out most physical attackers with Strength Sap and can disable their moves with Cursed Body. Giga Drain allows Polteageist to beat Obstagoon after a Strength Sap, prevents Milotic from using Haze, and provides useful recovery. Alternatively, Stored Power beats Normal-type Pokemon such as Porygon2 and Snorlax and gives a stronger neutral hit, although it makes Polteageist much more vulnerable to Dark-types, particularly Obstagoon. White Herb eases setting up and crucially lowers Knock Off damage after it's been used. The EV spread outspeeds Choice Scarf Flygon after boosting and allows Polteageist to take a Knock Off from Obstagoon at -1.

Pokemon commonly found on hyper offense such as Mimikyu, Necrozma, and Lucario complement Polteageist well, either helping break down its checks like Porygon2 or taking advantage of it weakening its checks itself like Swords Dance Incineroar to clean. Fighting-types like Lucario and Cobalion can deal with Normal- and Dark-types like Umbreon and Snorlax. Offensive support can greatly facilitate a Polteageist sweep. For example, Indeedee's Psychic Terrain can block priority and strengthen Polteageist's Stored Power. Alternatively, Misty Terrain from Galarian Weezing neutralizes Pokemon like Toxic Incineroar, Klefki, and Noivern. Spikes from Froslass or Focus Sash Heracross can help to weaken checks like Obstagoon.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Indeedee-M's primary role in the RU tier is as a wallbreaker that is capable of pushing past many neutrally hit, specially bulky targets. Mystical Fire hammers the likes of Steelix and Metagross for super effective damage while also lowering the Special Attack of switch-ins like Assault Vest Reuniclus, thus making it easier for Indeedee-M's teammates to switch into them. Shadow Ball can be used for a stronger hit against Assault Vest Reuniclus, while maintaining coverage against Metagross and Bronzong, but in turn misses out certain Steel-types like Registeel and Klefki. Hyper Voice is an alternative STAB move that gives Indeedee-M a more reliable move to lock into if Dark-types like Incineroar or Pangoro are present, notably being Indeedee-M's strongest option against the former. Trick can cripple special walls like Umbreon and Registeel to make it even easier for Indeedee-M's team to deal with them, but losing its Choice Specs makes Indeedee-M much less effective at breaking down defensive cores. Dazzling Gleam OHKOes Guzzlord and can 2HKO Umbreon after some prior damage.

Indeedee-M appreciates teammates that can handle extremely bulky Psychic-type answers, particularly Umbreon and Registeel. Fighting-types such as Lucario and Heracross can handle these threats and clean up late-game once Indeedee-M has broken down an opponent's defensive core. Spikes support from Roserade and Klefki is also appreciated, as it can allow Indeedee-M to push past Umbreon on its own with Dazzling Gleam while also exploiting Registeel's lack of reliable recovery on repeated switch-ins. Faster threats, such as Crobat, Choice Scarf Xurkitreee, and Choice Scarf Heracross have problems switching in but can easily revenge kill Indeedee-M. Pokemon like Metagross and Nidoqueen can check these threats and set Stealth Rock. Sharpedo and Cloyster are powerful late-game cleaners that benefit from Psychic Terrain protecting them from dangerous priority moves. Pokemon such as Milotic and Flygon can utilize pivot moves to effectively switch in Indeedee-M on favorable matchups.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Indeedee-M's good Speed and Psychic Surge-boosted Expanding Force allows it to revenge kill numerous RU staples, such as Noivern, Raikou, and Crobat, with a Choice Scarf equipped. Mystical Fire 2HKOes bulkless Metagross and can make it easier for teammates to switch into Psychic-resistant Pokemon, such as Reuniclus. Hyper Voice hits Incineroar the hardest and does more to Psychic-types like Gardevoir and Starmie. Trick is essential for crippling special walls like Registeel, Umbreon, and Porygon2.

Indeedee-M has a very hard time with special walls, particularly Umbreon, Registeel, and Porygon2. This makes Pangoro, Lucario, and Heracross great teammates, as they can easily remove these special walls and weaken most defensive Pokemon in general with their powerful attacks. Flygon is a troublesome faster Choice Scarf user that can revenge kill Indeedee-M, thus making Togekiss and Vileplume good teammate options. Togekiss can utilize a Nasty Plot set to weaken or outright remove Steel-types for Indeedee-M, while Vileplume can potentially punish U-turns with Effect Spore. Spikes from Roserade and Klefki is also appreciated, as all of the special walls Indeedee-M struggles with are vulnerable to the entry hazard. Late-game cleaners, such as Sharpedo and Cloyster, that appreciate Psychic Terrain protecting them from opposing priority moves are good choices to use with Indeedee-M as well.

sets.name: Hail Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Slush Rush Arctovish uses its Fishious Rend and boosted Speed to plow through defensive and offensive threats alike. Fishious Rend's incredible power puts immense pressure on any Pokemon that does not resist it, OHKOing frailer Pokemon such as Raikou and 2HKOing bulkier Pokemon such as Registeel and Galarian Weezing. Freeze-Dry hits Water-types, OHKOing Gastrodon after Stealth Rock and Seismitoad from full health, 2HKOing Jellicent after some chip damage, and activating Golisopod's Emergency Exit. Icicle Crash 2HKOes Grass-types such as Celebi and Vileplume, as well as OHKOing Roserade. Substitute allows Arctovish to take advantage of forced switches and allows for easier prediction. Protect is an option to beat First Impression Golisopod and scout faster Choice-locked Pokemon such as Gardevoir and Flygon. The given EV spread allows Arctovish to OHKO Gastrodon and Seismitoad with Freeze-Dry after Stealth Rock and outspeed up to Choice Scarf Rotom-C under hail. A Choice Band set is a fine alternative, dishing out immense power with Fishious Rend. However, its inability to OHKO Seismitoad and Gastrodon and the availability of Water-immune Pokemon make it significantly more prediction reliant.

Slush Rush Arctovish requires a hail-setting teammate. Vanilluxe can wallbreak independently and thus is best suited to semi-hail, while dedicated hail teams use a combination of Abomasnow and Aurorus to support its sweepers. Alolan Sandslash synergizes with Arctovish, as one can weaken or beat their checks to open the other up for a sweep. Because Arctovish is weak to Stealth Rock, it appreciates entry hazard control from Pokemon such as Xatu, Dhelmise, Starmie, Crobat, and Flygon. Flygon can check the Fire-type Pokemon such as Chandelure that threaten hail teams and bring Arctovish in safely with U-turn. Similarly, Starmie can pivot into Water-types and Teleport out while keeping hazard setters like Registeel, Bronzong, and Steelix at bay. Because Gardevoir can copy Slush Rush with Trace and counter-sweep hail teams, sturdy answers such as Metagross and Registeel are required on semi-hail. Because Arctovish is unable to break through some bulky Water-types such as Milotic and Suicune, Grass- and Electric-type teammates are important. On semi-hail, Pokemon like Roserade, Nasty Plot Celebi, and Calm Mind Raikou are highly valuable. Roserade can support Arctovish with Spikes, while Raikou and Celebi pair very well with Arctovish offensively. On full hail, Pokemon like Toxicroak or Heliolisk can deal with Water-types. Lastly, checks to Steel-types like Registeel and Cosmic Power Metagross are important, so Pokemon like Xatu and Doublade are good choices.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
Dragon Dance Regidrago is a solid late-game sweeper once key roadblocks are removed. Regidrago's average-to-good bulk and Dragon typing lend it many setup opportunities against bulky Water-types such as Milotic and Suicune, but also against passive walls like Registeel. However, even after a boost, Regidrago is slower than every common Choice Scarf user. The Speed raise from Scale Shot can prevent Choice Scarf users from revenge killing Regidrago after setup, but it's inconsistent due to its variability in power. After a Dragon Dance, Thunder Fang 2HKOes even bulky Togekiss. Substitute helps Regidrago set up by blocking Scald burns and Toxic. The passive recovery from Leftovers means Regidrago can use Substitute many more times throughout a battle. An Adamant nature is preferable to ensure the 2HKO on Togekiss with Thunder Fang after a Dragon Dance.

Try as it might, Regidrago can't break through Steelix, Galarian Weezing, Diancie, and Stakataka. Luckily, wallbreakers like Starmie and Golurk can pick up the slack and blow past each one with relative ease. Fighting-types such as Guts Heracross, Bewear, and Pangoro can also overwhelm Diancie and Galarian Weezing while breaking Steelix and Stakataka. Crobat, Flygon, and Incineroar can safely switch Regidrago into the battlefield with U-turn. Flygon and Incineroar synergize particularly well with Regidrago, as they can bring it in against bulky Water-types for a setup opportunity. Disguised as Regidrago, Zoroark can lure Galarian Weezing, Sylveon, Steelix, and Doublade with coverage moves in Extrasensory, Sludge Bomb, and Flamethrower. Dragon Dance Regidrago fits well on dual screens hyper offense teams, as it can get multiple boosts with ease thanks to its titanic bulk under dual screens. One notable Pokemon commonly seen on dual screens hyper offense is Cloyster; after a Shell Smash, it can OHKO Galarian Weezing with Hydro Pump and can wear down Steel-types. Other hyper offense staples like Sharpedo and Mimikyu can also help with breaking bulky Steel-types.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Choice Band Dragon's Maw-boosted Outrage is a sight to behold, but in a tier infested with Fairy- and Steel-types, Regidrago finds its effectiveness limited. Nevertheless, with good team support, Regidrago is a force to be reckoned with. Scale Shot is decently strong and doesn't lock Regidrago in like Outrage does. The Speed raise also makes it harder to revenge kill with faster threats like Noivern and Starmie. Hammer Arm is Regidrago's best move to hit Diancie as well as Steel-types such as Steelix and Registeel. Thunder Fang is a near-guaranteed 2HKO on max HP Togekiss. Explosion is an alternative over either Outrage or Scale Shot, as it opens the door for Regidrago's teammates by either severely weakening or outright KOing Togekiss, Grimmsnarl, or Galarian Weezing. Crunch is also an option to hit Doublade and 2HKO Metagross and Bronzong but has no other relevant targets.

Regidrago can do next to nothing against Sylveon, Galarian Weezing, and Doublade. Toxtricity is noteworthy for dealing with the mentioned Pokemon and weakening Steelix, which repeatedly switches in on Regidrago otherwise. Fighting- and Dark-types like Heracross and Sharpedo can pair with Regidrago to overwhelm shared checks, such as Fairy-types. Regidrago can also lure and severely weaken Fairy-types with Explosion so its Fighting- and Dark-type teammate can clean up afterward. Zoroark can disguise itself as Regidrago with Illusion to lure and surprise Fairy-types with a super effective Sludge Bomb. Pivots like Raikou, Milotic, and Flygon are excellent for safely bringing Regidrago onto the field. Flygon and Fire-types like Entei and Incineroar are grateful for Regidrago breaking bulky Water-types such as Milotic and Gastrodon. Spikes support from Roserade and Klefki helps whittle down sturdy Steel-types like Steelix, Metagross, and Doublade.
